reviewText: Maybe I am biased, being from the UK, but anyone who does not find this series very very funny, has lost their funny bone. It is international comedy at it's very best. Forget Tony Robbins for your daily dose of anti  depressant motivation, if you are not laughing hysterically after watching  CLEESE, Robbins has no hope. Recomended without any hesitation. A BRILLIANT  COMEDY MASTERPIECE.
love this comedy..
Very Funny TV Show From England.
I used to watch this with my very British mom years ago.  I still laugh at Basil as much now, as I did when I first saw this series.  Thank you for restoring old memories for me.

I ordered this product as a Valentine gift along with Keeping Up Appearances for my wife.  I simply love Brit humor.  It is clean, fun and something the entire family can enjoy.  I don't particularly care for humor that has to use foul language or make political statements at others expense.  This series does not do that.  As a matter of fact, it is so darn funny I actually got my kids and grandkids watching Fawlty Towers.  The only problem is, I really, really wish John Cleese would have produced many, many more episodes of Fawlty Towers.  I mean I watch this over and over again and still laugh at the same stuff.  Wife does the same and she simply loves John Cleese.

Brilliant! The trials and tribulations of Basil Fawlty and his small English hotel. He is accompanied by his wife Sybil, hostess Polly and his bell hop Manuel(whose English leaves much to be desired). Poor Basil attempts to be perfect but seems to always falls short with hilarious results. Each episode follows Basil's attempt to find this perfection. The show has a great cast of regulars and plays their contributions to the limit. Overall a laugh riot.
Hysterically funny! My family laughs through each episode and they never get old!

Nowhere in the credits does it say that "Fawlty Towers" is actually based on true events, but John Cleese has repeatedly admitted that the character of Basil Fawlty is modeled after a hotel proprietor the members of Monty Python's Flying Circus met in real life.

As bewildering as the stay in that very hotel must have been, it obviously inspired Cleese and Connie Booth, to whom he was married at the time, to come up with a memorable show that has aged astoundingly well - although "Fawtly Towers" has been with me for a while, I find most of the episodes as funny today as when I first became aware of the series on a day I picked up a copy of "The Germans" in a small shop in Ireland. Back then, I bought the VHS tape out of sheer curiosity - even while I was a great Monty Python's fan back then, I had never heard of "Fawlty Towers" before (it would be years before a badly dubbed version would appear on German television), but I guessed that anything that John Cleese was involved in, couldn't really be bad.

When I first watched the "The Germans" episode, I literally howled with laughter, and even today I know whole passages from that episode by heart. Among others, the episode features what today is probably the most famous "Fawlty Towers" quote of the all, namely "Don't mention the war" - a line that in the mind of a rather paranoid Basil Fawlty is the best advice when it comes to dealing with guests from Germany. Alas, mentioning the war is exactly what Fawlty himself seems unable to avoid, and in end the blundering hotel owner once again succeeds in utterly annoying his guests.

Other personal highlights include the episode "The Builders" in which Fawlty commissions a band of Irish builders with reconstruction work inside the hotel - unbeknownst to his wife Sybil, who is aware that builder O'Riley and his men mightwell  be the cheapest gang you can hire, but are sadly lacking with regard to professionalism. O'Riley - a character who is as stage Irish as it gets - is just one of a number of truly memorable, endearing characters that turn up in Fawlty's Hotel; others include a retired British major who is constantly on the road from tipsy to turvy, Basil's resolute wife Sybil, hard-working chamber-maid Polly and, of course, Manuel, the Spanish waiter ("I speak good English - I learn it from abook ... !")

If you're a fan of Monty Python's, you're probably familiar with Basil Fawlty and his antics. And if not? Look forward to a classic British comedy series offering lots of bizarre situations and unforgettable characters - "Fawlty Towers" is mandatory viewing, and the "Complete Collection" does the show justice.

The basic situation is that there is a small hotel called "Fawlty Towers" after the proprietors Mr. & Mrs. Fawlty. We get a mixture of cerebral and slapstick humor as Basil tries to promote the hotel and many times his schemes backfire. Of course this would not be so funny without all the supporting characters helping snowball small situations into something ridiculously absurd.

"Fawlty Towers", in my opinion, is one of the finest comedy series ever produced! John Cleese, Connie Booth and the others formed an amazingly talented and comedic ensemble. I have recently upgraded from VHS format to DVD as I cannot live without this great collection!

Not only are all 12 of the episodes are here in this excellent series, but some bonus interviews with the cast, and actors who have appeared in episodes during the run of the series. I especially enjoyed seeing and hearing Andrew Sachs, talk about his experience on the show. Prunella Scales who is sadly suffering from the effects of Alzheimer's Disease, was showing signs of the beginning of her illness in one of the interviews, it was painful to watch.

It's understandable that John Cleese and Connie Booth required two months to write each episode; the quality shows in the product. This is perfectly timed farce, and may have been the best sitcom in television history.

Even if you are not a Monty Python fan, this is possibly the funniest TV series I have ever watched. Full of visual gags as well as devastatingly episode scenarios and dialogue.  Too bad there were only 13 episodes. Try not to be rolling in the aisle over the spoiled kippers episode.  John Cleese is an absolute riot as the worst hotel proprietor in the history of business. Always look at the opening credits for the letter change of the sign like "Farty Towels" or "Fatty Owls".  Everyone in the cast is superb including the permanent guests, guest stars, and permanent cast. Unfortunately just lost the actor who played Manuel (QUE?), but I think everyone else is still with us. Buy it and laugh your kippers off.

If you enjoy  British humour, you'll love this set of 12 hilarious farces. Bound to hit the funny bone. If you don't remember John Cleese, think a Fish Named Wanda & Ferious Creatures, both hilarious as are each & every episode on these discs. His real life wife, Connie Booth, ( at the time) stars along side him in the role of Polly, general dogsbody at the humble hotel. Then along with his stage wife, the long suffering Mrs. Sybil Fawlty, played by Prunella Scales we see Andrew Sachs take on the role of non-english speaking busboy, waiter & whipping boy for Basil Fawlty, hotel manager extrodinare!

There are many extras incld a Torquay Tourist Guide & a Cheap Tatty Review which I thoroughly enjoyed!

Manuel is an annoying one joke character.  Whenever anyone says anything to him he responds  "Que? Que?"  Mildly amusing the first time, but by the hundredth time you may have a different opinion.  Also what is that woman who plays Basil Fawlty's wife doing in a sit-com?  She is so grim that she sucks the very possibility of humor right out of the room.  I understand that she's supposed to be the straight woman to all of the zaniness but come on.  The fact that John Cleese shrieks half his lines doesn't help either.  There is a lot of slapstick so if you're into that sort of thing you may like this more than I did.

An extremely funny series that bears rewatching just for all of the quick witty humor, the goofy visual slapstick, and just to watch poor, befuddled Basil Fawlty try desperately to work his way out of ridiculous situations at his hotel. The timing of the gags is remarkable, and you need subtitles just to keep up with some of the zany dialog. "The Germans" would have to be the best of the series, with John Cleese revisiting his Monty Python "silly walk" while doing an atrocious Hitler impression to the shock and horror of his German hotel guests. Sure, the series can be a tad offensive with some of it's dialog (and far from politically correct) and there's an occasional scantly-clad individual, but otherwise the series is driven by very clever and hilarious dialog and goofy slapstick (poor Manuel).

On a recent rewatch I was interested to see David Kelly of "Waking Ned Devine" as the inept repairman in episode "The Builders". Another good episode in a very funny series.

After appearing in the groundbreaking series "Monty Python's Flying Circus," John Cleese co-wrote and starred in a more traditional British sitcom entitled "Fawlty Towers." Accurately described as a fast-paced farce, six episodes were originally broadcast in 1975, while the final six episodes were originally broadcast in 1979. In addition to playing Polly, Connie Booth co-wrote the episodes with John. They were married during the first season of the series, but had divorced before the second season. As a testament to their talent, there is no discernible difference in the characters between the two seasons. Prunella Scales played the domineering Sybil Fawlty, Basil's wife. The English actor Andrew Sachs played Manuel, the hapless waiter from Barcelona, who is trying to learn English, and is fiercely loyal to Basil. Special mention must be made of Major Gowen, played by Ballard Berkeley. He has retired from the military, and is a permanent resident at the hotel. The Major is also permanently befuddled, and spends most of his time drinking in the hotel's bar.

What makes Basil such a fascinating character are his contradictions. He fawns over British lords and ladies, but openly shows contempt for everyone else. He has a dominating personality, yet is henpecked and afraid of his wife. Similarly, the show's dialogue is very witty, yet a good deal of the comedy comes from physical humor. "The Germans" episode is my favorite, when Basil admonishes his staff to not mention the war. After getting hit on the head several times and suffering from a concussion, he can't refrain from mentioning Hitler and the war. Basil's walk - a combination of the Minister of Silly Walks and a goose-stepping Nazi - is the most outrageous, hilarious and memorable scene in the entire series. The remastering of the series is superb; the show looks like it was filmed in high-definition. Every episode includes a commentary by John Cleese. The bonus disc includes 2009 interviews with John Cleese, Connie Booth, Prunella Scales, and Andrew Sachs, as well as older interviews with Cleese, Sachs and Scales. Also included is a short documentary about the seaside resort of Torquay, the real hotel that Fawlty Towers is based on, and the hotel's late owner, who inspired the character of Basil Fawlty. The disc concludes with artist profiles, some brief out-takes, and a cheap tatty review. I highly recommend spending some quality time at Fawlty Towers.

John Cleese based this series on an experience he had had with a very rude hotel proprietor.  Yes, it's meant to be a farce, yes, it has stereotypical characters, but it seems that so many people rate this series along with Citizen Kane.  I suspect Cleese himself must have been shocked by just how highly-regarded this series had become.

Face it, the proprietor is simply a jerk.  Rude, obnoxious, nasty, and screaming like a banshee, occasionally slipping into sycophancy whenever the occasion comes.  Fawlty gets into all sorts of scrapes, often caused by his own folly, and everyone else has to put up with it.  The series might have really been good if there were some reason to root for Fawlty-but there isn't.

Yes, sometimes it can be very clever.  Fawlty schemes to hide his gambling winnings from his wife-but his efforts fail even when they go perfectly according to plan.  But there are ridiculous jokes, such as the overdone joke about forgetting his wife's anniversary, and much of the humor involves "the funny little foreign man" Manuel or other ethnic stereotypes, such as the proper epithet for Indians-which is more offensive than funny.

Fawlty Towers was very funny at times, but it's hardly the greatest sitcom ever.  I've found more laughs in less famous ones.

John Cleese is without peer. The humor of the set up in the series is almost nonstop. About a selfimportant man and his huffy wife who thinks he's a self important twit, while being an annoying  one herself. The dynamics between them and Manuel, their waiter from Barcelona who hardly speaks English is a constant meal of sight gags, misunderstandings and John Cleese's patented exasperated outrage and bluster. This series only lasted two seasons but is hysterical much of the time.

Hotel owner Basil Fawlty has a farcical point of view of life that defies normalcy and which effortlessly gets him into trouble.  To extricate himself, Basil effortlessly designs and uses extreme, magnificent, outlandish planning to get out of trouble.  Long suffering wife and sometimes explosive Sybil, seems to be bored with her ability to expect and predict lunacy.  She has at times wondered why she ever married this nut case - but she hangs on.  The chambermaid, Polly, a struggling artist, is sympathetic to her employer's woes and tries to help him.  She does so as directed but her aid causes escalation because Basil's impatience requires him to micromanage the plan to a deeper disaster.  Manuel.  Ah, Manuel; from Barcelona, the hapless waiter who takes the brunt and blame for most if not all of Basil's antics to extricate himself out of trouble and get back at some of his interesting and at times eccentric hotel guests.

Some of the humor has historic aspects that may not now seem appropriate or funny, just like standup comedy of 90 years ago is not as funny to today's audiences.  However, there are many zany, crazy moments, and plots that defy logic, sanity and improbable successes that somehow end up as success in the mind of the oblivious Basil Fawlty.  This man's particular paradigm of life as it should be, is meant to be enjoyed by all.  These twelve shows and cast of many delightful characters will provide you lots of fun.  Enjoy.

These 12 shows collectively represent some of the best British comedy of all time. Chock-full of great ensemble performances, including John Cleese in his prime. Each time I see them, I get a belly laugh. Even if you don't usually like British comedy, you'll probably love this. In a way, it's a British version of "The Honeymooners"--not in plot, but in the way the characters stay true to their characters, which is excruciatingly funny. Que?

A must-have for anyone's collection of British humor. Whilst the interviews are great to see again, most are publicly available at no cost online. I was very disappointed to find only a few short minutes of Out Takes, as I am certain the behind-the-scenes and related footage was just as funny. It's a shame that more of such was not included in this collection. Discs 1 and 2 contain the 13 total episodes, while disc 3 is merely the interview and some other poorly-assembled, minimal quantity footage. This is the one area I was truly hoping to see more.

Dont know how much more you can say. John Cleese is a tour de force as a snooty,nosey and utterly belligerent hotelier on the "English Riviera" in this 12 episode drama that was made in 2 distinct -6 episode segments 5 years apart . Co-written and co-starring was his wife at the time,Connie Booth, the show takes place almost exclusively in the hotel's interior. Some people don't always understand British humor,but there is no problem here with any acquired taste. Cleese and Booth have taken farce with a fair amount of slapstick and turned it into almost non-stop sight and sound gags. Prunella Scales as his long suffering wife,Andrew Sachs is hilarious as the bellboy/waiter from Barcelona and Booth who plays the maid make the ensemble a formidable group at 'Fawlty Towers'. This show isn't just funny,it's fall on the floor funny and though the show is now 40 years old it still works. I prefer the tapes to having to watch it on public-TV with all of the endless begging for your money interrupting these glorious and timeless comedies.

This show is one of the most brilliant examples of timeless comedy I've ever seen. It's slapstick, but it's intelligent. It's chaotic, but it flows well. It's over-the-top, but you can relate. The comedy draws from interesting likeable characters in fairly realistic hotel based scenarios and watching it all fall apart as they scramble to pick up the pieces, instead of crude, stupid gross-out humor that most comedies of today rely on, with lazy writing playing to the dumbest of audiences. The writing here is outstanding, and clearly a labor of love. The show also serves as an excellent example of quitting while you're ahead. With only twelve episodes, it leaves you wanting more, which is far better than overstaying your welcome and becoming boring.

The picture in the edition is so much better than the original broadcast and our old VCR tapes were. The digital re-mastering fixed a lot of problems. The flimsy sets really show up now. They were probably built by O'Reilly. The color is still flat from the original videotaping (typical BBC rubbish camerawork through the 80's), but the show is so good that really doesn't matter.

This is John Cleese at his best as Basil Fawlty the owner of a hotel called Fawlty Towers. The show has a great supporting cast also.

Here are my favorite episodes:

A Touch of Class - Basil places an ad in the paper to attract a better class of people to stay at the hotel. But a con man posing as Lord Melbury decides to stay at the hotel. This is a very funny episode which provides a great start for this series.

The Hotel Inspectors - Sybil (Basil's wife) tells Basil that she has heard a group of hotel inspectors are in town. Basil thinks he knows which guest it is and the fun begins.

Gourmet Night - Basil decides to have gourmet night at the hotel to bring in a better class of people to the hotel. But the new cook gets drunk and everything goes wrong after that.

The Germans - Basil tells the staff "Don't mention the war" when a group of Germans are staying at the hotel. But of course he can't seem to follow his own instructions.

Waldorf Salad - Basil tries to fill in for the cook who leaves early. Of course he messes everything up when trying to serve a couple staying at the hotel.

Basil The Rat - this was my favorite episode overall. Manuel the waiter has a pet rat which he named Basil. Unfortunately the rat is loose when a health inspector is in the hotel. Watching Basil (John Cleese) trying to hide Basil (the rat) from the hotel inspectors is hysterical.

My least favorite episode was The Builders. But even a "bad" episode of Fawlty Towers is better than the best episode of most other comedies.
excellent quality and sound is great can't stop laughing and it puts me in a good mood when I need to cheer up

Bar none...NOTHING on TV, past or present, English or American...is as funny as this!!  Seriously!!  Now, some come VERY close (Monty Python, The Young Ones), but this towers above all else...so much lunacy and originality in one short, tidy, compact little package.  I used to have the first set, which I had bought based on hearsay, people mentioning that "Fawlty Towers" is the "Sistine Chapel Of Sitcoms" for instance...and I agreed...I laughed so hard I almost bust a gut...but I had to sell a lot of things to acquire some needed cash, and haven't seen this show in quite a while.  I remembered how much of a joy it was to watch, and always loved John Cleese's work, both comedic and dramatic, like on the Harry Potter movies.

Well, to my delight and surprise, I came upon this newer & improved set at the library...promptly took it out, and was delighted and reminded how superb this show is, top to bottom...from the writing (amazing and movie-worthy), to the acting, attention to detail, and the utter bravery to stick to the original vision and just "go for it", no matter the situation, as silly and perverse as they may be.  These episodes (and whole series really) is like a favourite album by your fave band...it always gives and gives, it's an utter delight, reveals new details with each sitting...and it's only 12 episodes, so each one is like a fave song...and you can always go back to it and watch each one over and over without getting sick of it.

This series is better than most US sitcoms because it just goes for it into wacky lunacy, physical slapstick (surprised no one got seriously hurt!!) & classic British farce, without losing the sense of dialogue or plot.  The writing (mostly by stars John Cleese and then-wife Connie Booth...who plays the utterly sane straight-woman maid/waitress Polly) is brilliant and timeless...this stuff just does NOT get old!!  The characters are iconic...Cleese who plays the exasperated and totally RUDE Basil Fawlty, Prunella Scales who plays his too-serious wife Sybil...Connie Booth as Polly and, oh gosh, Andrew Sachs as the English-impaired, waiter-in-training from Barcelona, Manuel...what a fun bunch!!

This set is so fun, and the special features as good as the episodes...it's great that Cleese looks back on this series with affection, not negativity...this series clearly has a place in his heart, as it should...this show was as good as comedy gets, and even moreso...this thing should set the standard and I think it has...its rep is only growing plus it seems to get new fans every week, which is why "Fawlty Towers" never goes out of style.  Now, I read that Bob Newhart's show "Newhart" was an American show based on "Fawlty Towers"...but the only similarity is that both are based out of a hotel & its staff...I canNOT see how "Newhart" is as funny as "Fawlty Towers", no way no HOW...nothing against the funny Bob Newhart though.

PS...Also, I LOVE the fun details on the show too, like the misspelled signs, hahaha...bring on the riff raff!!

I had been looking for this particular PBS series for years. Should have looked on Amazon first.  Great British humor!  John Cleese is hilarious.  Glad I own it.  Great for a weekend when you need a good laugh.

My gosh, the hamster (Basil the rat), the moose, the drunk chef, O'Reilly, Sybil, Manuel, Polly, the list just goes on and on!  If you enjoy John Cleese's work in television and in movies you will really like Fawlty Towers!  I've gotta go insert a gnome into O'Reilly so I'll sign off for now!  Thanks for letting me throw in my two cents, Vince

Basil Fawlty is rude, misanthropic, snobbish, miserly and likable in the strangest way possible. His domineering wife spends most of her free time on the phone, his waiter from Barcelona only knows a handful of English words and Polly, although highly intelligent, cannot always keep the hotel running smoothly. Through sheer cunning Basil, with Polly's assistance, can conceal the truth from his wife for the better portion of the series. In the end his lies are discovered and he ends up worse off than when he began. In the interim he spits venom at sometimes deserving targets, interacts with the senile Major and tries to manage Manuel. The plots are always tightly knit and the acting is superb. Also, for an American viewer the various British accents featured in the series add another layer of humor.
Wonderful to finally own the entire "Fawlty Towers" series.  Just a shame they didn't do more!  Shipping was a bit slow, but product is fine.

Mom asked for this for Christmas.  I had it shipped to my brother AJ's apt. so he could wrap and bring it to her. He asked if he could unwrap it and watch it first and I said "not really, it's a gift".  Mom called and when I told her I shipped her present to AJ to wrap, she said "thank you, I watched it and it's great".  I told her "but it was a present, you were supposed to wait til Christmas" and she replied "oh so you DID get me Fawlty Towers for Christmas!".  What a sneaky, devious little trick she played on me to find out what her gift was. So I told AJ to could go ahead and unwrap it and watch it.  HA!

Cleese, as always, is hilariously brilliant! These 12 episodes of his post Monty Python venture into more conventional SIT COM territory, all play up both his physical and cerebral shenanigans to the max.  Always cowering to his wife's constant reminders of his failed strategies to improve things at their shore side hotel, Basil Fawlty's (Cleese) continuous passive aggressive snarling and snake tongued barbs aimed at co-star Prunella Scales (playing his wife), are priceless.  Even if you weren't a fan of the Pythons, you will love these shows and want to watch them over and over.

There is a 'missing' episode.

The Pilot episode for Fawlty Towers was made in Black and White.  A common practice 'in the day.'  However, that episode is 'Brilliant' also, and very hard to find !

So, there are 13 of these 'Brilliant' jewels !

For our nation's notoriously short memory a comedy series from the 1970's seems as ancient as the Fall of Rome. By that I do not refer to the season. This series debuted in 1975, one of the years a number of our college campuses claimed to have invented sex. By contrast Basil Fawlty, the lead character played by John Cleese, was hopelessly repressed, as blissfully insensitive as they come and possibly, some might add, as self-centered as our culture has generally become today. Cleese and his then wife and co-star, Connie Booth, did a brilliant job of writing 12 classic episodes with remarkable consistency in quality. Once writers establish such a rare, high level as their standard, all successive episodes must have become intimidating to try to emulate. I believe that accounts for the series being so short. Rather than keep cashing the checks, the writers wanted the series to end while all episodes were consistently excellent rather than continue and risk sliding into mediocrity. In any case, it was one of the shortest, and arguably, the best written comedies on TV.

This brief, physical, farcical, linguistically playful, and clever humor greet the viewer today with as much intelligence, glee and irreverence as almost 40 years ago. Each episode plays with and counter to our notions regarding good manners, guilty titillation, irrationality, as well as lampooning a variety of national, ethnic, and gender stereotypes including Brits and Yanks. It was all fair game and almost always hilarious. Even the most outrageous script still managed to avoid being outright mean or cruel. Secondly, the bigoted, vain, greedy, foolish, lazy lout called Basil, managed to end up the prime recipient of retributive justice -- to our delight -- every show. He was too thick to ever learn his lesson, thank goodness. The supporting cast was also brilliant and essential as an early triumph of an ensemble comedy.

Highly recommended for anyone who loves British humor, those who appreciate analytical comedic writing, and for all of us who can laugh at the outrageously silly. But humor, like everything else dealing in personal taste, is a highly subjective matter. If you have never seen it, please use the magic of VOD or streaming to see if you like it before you buy it.

The only criticism I have is to acknowledge that some of the plots have aspects that have not aged as well as others. We live in a different time with our own cultural and social sensibilities. For example, today humor making fun of gay stereotypes in particular is out of step with the majority of Americans and practically everyone else. IMO these jokes simply fall a bit flat today. I can't reject them solely on the basis of their being in bad taste because after all that was one of the fundamental principles of the show's humor. One could argue if it succeeded because of or in spite of its questionable taste.

Basil embodies bad taste. His countless flaws are a pantheon of human weaknesses. Much of what makes this series so endearing and enduring is that it underscores many recognizable human frailties that are just as prevalent today as they were then. Yes, if you happen to be more familiar with British culture you will get a little more out of it but it is its universal appeal that carries it. Moreover, comedy in the hands of such gifted, bright, insightful writers and such an outstanding cast will help Fawlty Towers continue to delight new generations. Basil the Rat, despite himself, has earned his place in Western comedic history today as Basil the Icon.

I have owned the VHS boxed set of Fawlty Towers for a long time, and have been waiting for the DVD version to come out for at least five years.  When it finally does come out, it is a complete disappointment, as usual.

Once again, BBC has overcompressed the show you care about so they can include a partially filled disc of Extras that no one cares about.

The set has "Remastered" plastered across the front, and on the startup menu of each of the shows.  The remastering must have been to reduce the video quality from the original as much as possible.

I have been on the point for years of transferring my VHS copies to DVD, since it seemed like it was never going to get released.  I think I might have gotten better quality that way, even though, per the BBC long-standing policy of assuring that classics are preserved for posterity in the shoddiest possible manner, they are recorded at four-hour format instead of two-hour like they should have been.

All twelve episodes are crammed onto two DVDs, assuring the lowest possible video quality and the maximum possible degredation.

As if that weren't enough, they make you sit through a full five minutes of FBI warnings and ads for other BBC products before you can even get to the main menu!  Hit the Stop button at any point in this process, and then the Menu button just takes you back to the beginning of the FBI warning, and you have to sit through the whole five minutes again!

Once you finally do make it to the main menu, Prunella Scales is shouting something at four times the volume of the entire rest of the disk!

I do have to admit that the extras are better than usual.  The interviews are actually interesting.  The outtakes are better than just people blowing their lines, which is all they typically consist of.  But there are only four of them.  I can't imagine they take more than five or six minutes total.

Thanks again, Beeb, for seeing to it that another classic of twentieth century comedy goes down in history with absolute rock-bottom quality.

Ken Burns sets a new standard for historical documentaries that has influenced the genre to match his craft.  The use of professional actors to provide voice to the actual letters written by participants brings to life poingancy of the war that still shapes our nation.  His artristic movement of the camera over still photos brings realism to a war without th benefit of motion photography footage.  The research for the presentation is exhaustive and comprehensive.  This documentary should be required viewing for everyone wanting an understanding of the scope and magnitude of this civil war that was in no way civil in preserving the4 United States.  I recommend it for anyone whether middle school student, ordinaary citizen, or academic scholar.

Forever etched in the minds of FT fans is this short-lived British comedy series.  This 30th anniversary(!) re-mastered DVD edition crisply and faithfully delivers every complete episode containing all visual and aural gags written by the comedy team of John Cleese and wife Connie Booth.  The 30th anniversary DVD set edition is offered at a special value price.  Although Fawlty Towers is a superb period production, this immortal series delivers off-kilter insights on daily tribulations and strives to send messages applicable to today's viewer.  Indulge yourself, c'mon and buy this DVD set.  Be sure to listen to the out-takes and also view those episodes in which you can opt to listen to running commentary [delivered by John  Cleese himself] on the action, lines, and progress of each scene--as was intended or not.

In my opinion, this is the funniest TV series ever produced. There were only 12 episodes, separated by 4 years; the first series was in 1975, the second in 1979, by which time John Cleese and Connie Booth, who wrote it, were divorced. There were no more episodes, but what we're left with sets the standard for TV comedy.

Each episode is crammed full of funny lines and equally funny physical comedy. There's so much going on it's impossible to take it all in at one viewing. I've been watching it for 37 years now and it's still as funny as when I first saw it. Cleese, as Basil Fawlty the social-climbing hotel keeper, uses his unique physical attributes and his manic delivery to the utmost. Prunella Scales, as his acid-tongued wife, is a magnificent foil and Andrew Sachs as Manuel the trainee waiter ("He's from Barcelona" is the excuse for everything he does wrong) is one of the great comic creations in all of TV.

If by any chance you haven't seen Fawlty Towers, (or Farty Towels or Watery Fowls- even the credits are hilarious) just sit back and watch and prepare to fall about laughing. If you don't find it funny, well, I'll send Basil round to insert a garden gnome in you.

In 1971, John Cleese and the rest of the team from Monty Python's Flying Circus encountered rude treatment at a hotel. This experience led to the development of "Fawlty Towers," a sitcom that originally appeared on the BBC in 1975 and 1979. In the series, Cleese plays Basil Fawlty, manager of the Fawlty Towers hotel in Torquay on the Devon coast. Fawlty (mis)manages the hotel with his wife, Sybil (Prunella Scales), and with hired help Polly (Connie Booth) and Manuel (Andrew Sachs). The four trifle with both the guests and each other, and the show is witty with fast-paced dialogue and comedy of errors-style humor. Some of the situations the crew stumbles into involve botched hotel repairs, restaurant meals gone wrong, and an untimely death. The first two discs in this set contain the twelve episodes of the series, and there is a third bonus disc recalling this classic series that containing interviews, outtakes, and other material.
I am in my second viewing using Amazon Prime and the laughs keep coming.  This is British humor at its best.  Every character is perfect, the dialogue well-timed and the physical comedy hilarious.
This is the third of four Brit Coms that I wanted.  And it is funny.  A bit zany, but funny.  I only need to get the Keeping Up Appearances to complete my collection.

I have ALWAYS loved Fawlty Towers. I only reason I purchased the remastered version is for the interviews. I enjoyed them immensely. My question as to why the series wasn't continued has been answered. Apparently there had been enormous pressure to continue the series, but John Cleese and Connie Booth didn't want to continue them because they really believed they had reached their goal with the 12 episodes.
I also did not know that Connie Booth is an American actress. Another surprising thing is that The Builders episode is John Cleese's least favorite episode (it's my favorite).
I also enjoyed the interview with Andrew Sachs. It was interesting to find out that his first language is German.
I wish Connie Booth had also participated in the interviews. Apparently she has always refused to comment on Fawlty Towers until 2009 in a documentary. Too bad. I would have loved to hear her thoughts on the show.

If you're not interested in the interviews, don't purchase the remastered version. The interviews are the only difference. I'm glad I got it. I did recoup 3/4 of the money back, by selling my older set.

If I'm permitted but one TV comedy series to take with me to Hell -- assuming I'm cursed with the grievous misfortune to wind up there -- please, Saint Whomever, let it be FAWLTY TOWERS.

Despite only twelve side-splitting, laugh-till-ya-drop episodes of this British masterpiece, one could sit comfortably (even eagerly) by one's raging "fireplace," blithely basking in the bubbleheaded antics of Basil Fawlty & Co. from the moment of arrival, until...well, until Hell freezes over.
Have had the complete series on tape for several years but with the new dvd it does look a lot better and is more enjoyable. Late wife was English and loved this series while it was on TV.
A very funny, witty series.  John Cleese was hilarious! My sister told me about it and said that it was my kind of humor. She was right!

If you're not hip to this series, do yourself a favor and spend the money and get it. Hilarious writing, and great acting. John Cleese and Connie Booth crafted a masterpiece of British comedy! And there's GREAT commentary by John Cleese on each episode. Basil!!

Just love having these finally in DVD.  Brought back memories of family sitting around watching these on TV.  Had old copies on VHS and was very pleased with the quality of these DVD's.  My daughter had to borrow them right away to view.  Gave my parents a good laugh when we shared them on a recent trip. Really liked the history behind the show and the case artwork that they came in.  Makes the set even more special to us. Thanks ever so much!!
Ordered this DVD collection as a gift for my husband.  He is very pleased with the set.  Funny as ever!  Would recommend!

this series is easily on my top favorites list of bbc comedy.  (the others being "are you being served?"  "keeping up appearances" "mr. bean" "chef!"  "absolutely fabulous" "the thin blue line" "black adder" "only fools and horses" "monty python" among so many others).  i know i could watch these series streaming on various sites, yet it's the bonus content alone that's worth the purchase price.  john cleese's insight gives it so much more depth and meaning as to how he and connie booth came up with such clever story lines and dialogue.  this is a great series to introduce people to bbc comedy for the first time as it's something that takes time to get used to.
Fawlty Towers,well worth watching excellent for a good laugh. Great acting by all. Need a good sense of humoer. I thought it is was well worth the money.
I have always liked Fawlty Towers so I bought this for my husband for Christmas. He didn't like it. However, I still do so I gave it four stars.

I ordered this for my wife since she loves this series. It is very representative of British humor. The package came in a reasonable amount of time and have been very pleased with it. If you like slapstick humor, you will love this.

FAWLTY TOWERS is one of the most brillant BRITISH comedies ever. Just watch one episode and you will be hooked Amazon is the perfect place to find Classic Shows you've been looking for and at a great price.

What can you say about John Cleese?  Years ago, when the bride and I were considering B and B ownership as a life style, we had the opportunity to 'study' with a B&B guru from Vermont.  During the lesson plan, he strongly suggested that we students watch and learn from the PBS series 'Fawlty Towers' as THE REAL inside scoop on lodgings.  Until that course we had never heard of the show: we watched, learned and became hooked on the absolutely enthralled with this OUTSTANDING SHOW.
Classic show!  Bought it for my hubby for Xmas.. love rewatching all the episodes!  The best, of course, being the episode with the German.  Highly reccommend this gift!

Fawlty Towers remains one of my most cherished shows from Great Britian and for good reason.  There's never really been anything else quite like it on the tube, in either the UK or US.  John Cleese's adept comic skills and physical slapstick really take the show to the next level.  A wonderful supporting cast of characters (and actors) make the entire thing one uproarious set to own.  Even at its slowest it is still somewhat closer to 'manic' than 'metered' and is all the better for it.
Thank you for the dvd. This is a perfect xmas gift for my parents. I love this show and I know they will.
Another British Comedy that is excellent. A must see for those that love comedies.  They have a definite different sense of humor than American comedies.

Fawlty Towers has long been a family favorite. I was very happy to find a good deal which allowed me to share this with other friends. Excellent service at an excellent price for an absolute comedy classic. It's good to laugh and Basil and crew help you do just that. Watch them over and over and it just doesn't get old

John Cleese leads the way with humor and it's all fun.
  Set in an English hotel run by Basil Fawlty (John Cleese) and his wife where nothing goes right but always ends well.

I enjoyed Fawlty Towers many years ago on PBS.  It's been fun to watch them over again...they're still funny.  When I don't have time to watch a full length movie, I can watch one or two episodes.  I'm sorry they only made a few episodes.

Finally on DVD! Leave it up 2 the British 2 create the funniest series ever! Great timing on delivery, great wrapping, great quality of DVD's. I haven't seen these episodes in forever. Brought back memories, and thanks for doing that for me.

Epic show, the "remastered" edition doesn't seem too different to the origional DVD set i got around 5+ years ago...I took a side by side Screen shot, and it appears the main difference is a slight color correction (which on the opening scene looks like it was too yellow on the origional DVD's), and there appears to be some detail added back, as it appears slightly more grainy in the new one. Fawlty Towers, without a doubt, is the benchmark by which all British sitcoms are now measured.

In the typical short but sweet 12 episodes (2 series) it became an instantly memorable classic comedy.

Basily Fawlty (John Cleese) is the owner with his wife Sybill (Prunella Scales) of the quite infamous 'Fawlty Towers' Hotel in the English Riviera resort town of Torquay (Which is also where I happen to come from)

Along with the staff of Polly the maid (Connie Booth), Manuel the Waiter from Barcelona (Andrew Sachs) and Terry the chef (Brian Hall) much mayhem and chaos ensue with Basil landing them all in situations that end up with him ultimately paying the price for his bizarre behaviour.

There are a couple of regular guests at Fawlty Towers that add to the confusion, Major Gowen (Ballard Berkley) and Miss Tibbs & Miss Gatsby (Gilly Flower & Renee Roberts) who seem to enjoy staying at the Hotel even though Basil is frequently quite rude to them.

Now the complete collection has been remastered and released we can all re-live the genius of Fawlty Towers!

Hilarious show. Have watched the episodes numerous times and still
laugh outloud! If you like British comedy, or any type of slapstick, this is for you. Price was very good compared to the box and motar stores.

Always been a big fan of Cleese & Co and this is the best comedy series made ever!!
High quality in this box set.
A must buy if you haven't seen it.

John Cleese can make just about anyone laugh.  This series of shows is totally hilarious.  It is hard to decide which one is a most favorite because each episode has its own sort of theme and the cast seems perfect for the roles.  Too bad there aren't more of these shows.  Very worthwhile to get.
Fawlty Towers is a rare comedic treat. It ingeniously combines the mundane everyday with the absurd. A great stress reliever.

Truly the best and funniest 12 half hours ever presented on anything,anywhere by the best. Each episode is so filled with bitting humour and silliness that I can watch them over and over. I think "Basil the rat" is the  funniest thing I have ever seen. When everyone is looking for Manual's pet "Siberian Hamster" lost in the hotel dining room.. it has to be the crowing touch of any episode. and of course when Basil discovers the guest not eating his breakfast in bed in "The Kipper and the Corpse" there's another one snuffed it in the night. I cannot even describe the insanity of "The Germans" but to say I'll pass on the Prawns Goebbels.

This series was produced at the same time that my wife and I started a small hotel, only 50 miles from Torquay, Devon where Fawlty Towers is located.  It quickly became cult viewing amongst hoteliers and restaurateurs in Britain, and after 30 years, it is still very, very funny.
Funny and grate!

This is one of my Top-10-Funniest series of all time, even though there were only 12 episodes.
Cleese is a master at over-the-top inappropriate behavior, and his real-world wife Connie Boothe is great as the employee who constantly tries to help cover for him so his wife doesn't find out about his latest inept or un-PC-like actions.
English humor at it's best.
I bought this set of DVD'S for my husband for Christmas and they were one of his favorite gifts. Good quality product.

For British comedy in general and John Cleese in particular, The Fawlty Towers series is really a classic, and we've watched each episode countless times over the past twenty years. We gifted our two sons with the collection this Christmas as we knew they would enjoy having it, and now our granddaughters are begging to watch. It's amazing how we still catch something we hadn't previously each time we see an episode, and, of course, we always laugh. Great entertainment!

Thanks so much BBC.  Wish more comedies were like these.

In my opinion, this is the funniest show that's ever been on television.  It gets funnier the more often you watch it.  Because you know what's coming, you start laughing before it happens.  The cast is superb.  You can't go wrong buying this show.
It great to get my wife this dvd for XMAS; think I enjoyed it as much as she did. "Basil Rat" episode was the best! Nice picture quality and sound.

We watched all of them within a few days and even went back and watched a few over.  If you like British comedies then you should love these!

I bought this as a gift for my SIL he was delighted.

Having seen all the shows myself, I can only say that "Basil" is just too funny.

"Allo Allo" is a very good series too. The British making fun of the French during German occupied France

This is arguably one of the funniest series ever created.  Be sure to watch the "backstory" included with this connection.  This series is a perfect example of how somebody really funny can make the most wonderful lemonade when life gives him lemons.  If anything it's even funnier than 80% of the "Flying Circus" sketches.  I particularly recommend the episode entitled "Basil the Rat".

This series is so funny that it left me wanting more than a mere 12 episodes.  John Cleese, Andrew Sachs, and the other cast members are spot-on as the wacky people who run the Fawlty Towers inn on the English Riviera.  Assorted guests, mix-ups, disasters, and miscommunications create hilarity in every show.

John Cleese.

Funny.

That's it.

That's all you really need to know.

Sure, the series is a bit dated given the time it was filmed, but funny never goes out of style.

If you love a quick wit, some dry British humor, and a moment of slap stick or two, then give this show a try.

One of the funniest series ever on TV--in ANY country (that I've seen, anyway!) Cleese is brilliant--even though I've seen each of these episodes many, many times, I always find something new and funny in them. Poor Basil Fawlty--the precursor of such sad sack schlubs as Larry David and Michael Scott on the American "Office". Don't miss this--especially at this price!
