If you know and enjoy Fawlty Towers, already, get this for your mate. S/he will love you all the more; an episode before sleep is better than a cigarette, and who know?  Some episodes might make you stay up longer.

This is rudeness as we might wish we could employ it ... sometimes.

I love Fawlty Towers and have been a dedicated fan for decades, but this DVD, with each episode re-mastered is simply a must-have for any Fawlty Towers fan.  The re-mastering makes the episodes look great and of course, this is some of the best comedy to ever emerge from England.  A fantastic DVD that would be a great addition to any fan's collection!

My favorite of the three dvds in the set.
Buy the whole set if you are a fan of Monty Python.
It's cheaper and you'll be addicted to the show after one
episode.

I first saw 'Fawlty Towers' when I was about 14 and every episode had me in stitches. I can still watch it today 25 years later, and titter at the gags I have seen so many time before. Each episode has people running around like in a French farce, but the main source of amusement has to come from Basil Fawlty, uniquely portrayed by the talented John Cleese. That is not to say that the other actors and actresses were not brilliant, for they all were! It all worked to create seemless and hilarious comedy. 'Fawlty Towers' never had the chance to go stale as only two series were made, that is 12 episodes in all. It never ages, although you do need to put yourself back in time a bit to understwnd what's going on with the mad major. See this series at least once in your life!

My wife and I remember watching these episodes when they first aired back when they were new on the PBS station in S. Florida. Our kids,now with kids of their own, laughed right along with us.  These are to be treasured for sure and we highly recommend them to anyone needing a break from the day to day grind. It gives us a sense of release from stress just being able to laugh all over again at Basil's antics with Manuel. We still use some of the catch phrases around here and just now remember where they came from, like,  "I'll give you a damn good thrashing", when something goes wrong around the house. Lately I've been hearing " oooh, I know" a lot more from the wife. We are truly enjoying these all over again, thanks for preserving them on these fine quality CD's. We are looking for another set of 'old goodies' to purchase next.

If you haven't seen "Fawlty Towers," you are in for a treat. And if you have, this new set means you are in for a treat as well, with John Cleese's commentary. It's probably the most insightful DVD commentary I've ever heard, as Cleese, 30 years later, shows point by point how he and Connie Booth polished the scripts and how he thinks the writing, the performance or the direction could have been improved. You'll find he is a tough critic of his own work, but at some points he can't help it, the pride shines through at having created these miniature masterpieces. Watch each episode as broadcast first, then watch it again with the commentary on, and you'll learn a lot if you're so inclined. It's a master class in comedy writing. Or just sit back, hit "play" and laugh yourself hoarse. The only comparison is to early Marx Brothers or perhaps some of the great "I Love Lucy" episodes. Cleese's goal was to create, not a typical sitcom, but a classic farce, and he succeeded. In 2001 I was visiting the UK and there was one of those pop culture countdown shows on one of the TV channels, "The 100 Greatest TV Characters." Cleese's Basil Fawlty came in #2 behind Homer Simpson.

I have been a long time admirer of British humor and the man that sits at the head of that table is John Cleese.  I became a fan of the slap-schtick, one-liner comedy that describes what came out of the British Isles back in the mid-60's as I was located 40 miles outside of London for 5 years.
Mr. Cleese brought together a gaggle of troupers and became an icon almost overnight.  His ability to put out a weekly comedy sitcom made life so much easier as we were looking for anything to take us away.  As the years went on and age overtook me, I found "Fawlty Towers" and was able to get a giggle again.
There is nothing out there today that can compare to this brand of comedy.  It will live on longer than the dvd set I possess.
If anyone wishes to forget about their life's troubles, I would strongly suggest to rent a room at the Fawlty Towers.  The service is lousy but the laughs are free-of-charge.

Thank god lately there has been a trend for the best comedy shows to have no laugh track. 30 Rock is a shining example

It would be so, so great if Fawlty Towers would be remastered to make the laugh track optional. I've heard that some other shows have been released this way.

I mean, it's hard to review Fawlty Towers, one of the great television comedies of all times. This is the edition to get though. Good video quality and decent sound throughout. It really adds to the experience compared to the previous editions. Or perhaps, one is less distracted by the video. Either way, recommended. Five stars. Really pretty darned nice. Just go and buy it now, or get it from Netflix if you prefer.
This made a great gift.  It was listed at a great price, arrived quickly, and arrived in perfect condition.  I will definitely look at the seller's items for future purchases.

I don't believe there is any doubt that Fawlty Towers is the funniest show ever! There are only twelve episodes, but how could there be anymore?

Fawlty Towers is just so well written and filled with so much comedy it would probably have been impossible for the high standard of these shows to have continued. I was fortunate enough to have met John Cleese and work with him for about a week on a film. I asked him after he mentioned he'd like to do more television whether he'd ever make more Fawlty Towers. Cleese responded that he couldn't because more episodes could never live up to the public's expectations. I believe that he is absolutely correct.

The show has various types of comedy, but I believe farce is the main ingredient. Although there is a non-Spaniard playing Manuel the Spanish waiter, who speaks little English and understands less the character is show in a sympathetic light. He is not being made fun  of because he is a foreigner. In fact, the person who comes off the worst in this show is Basil Fawlty himself! Every nationality - almost - is made sport of in the show. Americans, Japanese and Norweigens, Irish, Greeks, French, Germans and most especially the English.

Literally there are laughs all around. There is ample helpings of the comedy of embarrassment, the deaf, senile, homosexual, upper class, lower class, the dead, old people, children, and psychiatrists are all made fun of. It is a very inclusive show which is NOT to be taken seriously.

We should all be thankful that we have 12 episodes of this great series. The extras on this complete collection are very good as well. The interviews with Cleese and Sachs are especially good.
I could watch this series once a week & still roar with laughter every time! It never ages & is brilliantly done.
"Fawlty Towers"...John Cleese in his prime.  Hilarious, and a shame it was only done for two seasons. Worth every penny.

No need to discourse on the merits of Fawlty Towers. I bought this set merely for the John Cleese commentaries, and I was not, for the most part, disappointed. His reminiscences about the regular cast members as well as the guests are really enjoyable, but the insights about the show's creation were unenlightening. His commentary was often incommoded by his laughter while he watched the episodes. This laughter was regularly accompanied by a horrid wracking cough which made me want to turn off the feature. The other special features were basically transferred from the previous box-set. The remastering was clear in both picture and sound. If you do not already own the F.T. box set, I would buy this one for the remastering and the previously unavailable commentaries (if you can handle John's coughing fits).
Very happy with the service Amazon provides.  The item sent on time in excellent condition. Every care was taken to details.  Thanks so much!

They only made twelve episodes....and then they stopped.
They could have gone further, but maybe Cleese was doing other things, maybe the money wasn't there, I'm not sure, it's not important. Bottom line is that, in my opinion, this ranks up there with the funniest TV shows of all-time.

Here's an example: in the crabby deaf old lady (Mrs. Richards) episode, Basil has been betting on the horses, just to try and win some of his own money, and to try to squeeze out from under the iron thumb of wife Sibyl. Of course, the domineering Sibyl vehemently disapproves of Basil doing just about anything on his own. She has suspicions, and cooly says, "Basil, you know what I'm going to do if I find out you've been betting on the horses, don't you?" Basil shakes his head and does his best to appear studious, then mutters under his breath, out of her earshot, "You'll have to sew 'em back on first!"

That is, his testicles! No American show would have been witty or daring enough to get that line in, forty years ago.

Same episode: Mrs. Richards and Basil in her hotel room, and she's complaining about the view. Basil sarcastically replies, "And just what did you expect to see out of a Torquay hotel room window? Sydney Opera House, perhaps? Hanging Gardens of Babylon? Herds of wildebeests sweeping majestically across the plains?"

The writing, the characters, the situations, the dialogue, it's all perfect.
I've seen some of these episodes a dozen times, and I've never gotten tired of them. This latest remastering is beautiful, particularly because of the improved picture quality and the inclusion of Cleese's commentary.

Here is a listing in no order of the TV shows I think are particularly funny, definitely a cut above your ordinary sitcom: Larry Sanders (may be the funniest show ever on TV, this side of pond or not); Seinfeld, Curb Your Enthusiasm, SCTV, The Fall and Rise of Reginald Perrin, Keeping Up Appearances, The League of Gentlemen, Little Britain, and Monty Python's Flying Circus.

The funniest comedy series EVER! Great writing with great performances! Farce at its finest. DVDs include interviews, outtakes, and commentary by John Cleese. There were some less than stellar things about these DVDs: The commentaries by the directors were deadly dull and the outtakes were too few and not that good. The worst thing was that there were only 12 episodes. If you are "down in the dumps", those 12 episodes will have you crying with laughter and rewinding to hear parts you were laughing too loudly to hear.
I am thrilled to have this fabulous series at my fingertips.  Excellent!  I wish there were more...
You like Monty Python you'll love this.  Short and sweet, only a single season.
Service was excellent - I believe there were no shipping charges.  Price was most reasonable and the videos are all good quality.  I would definitely buy from this supplier again.

It's too bad these shows are not on DVDs.  But we remembered and enjoyed the television series so much, we decided to buy old technology just to have the shows available in our home.  We laughed till we cried!

We love Fawlty Towers, and we already had the video collection from several years ago, but this new DVD set is well worth the price to get the new John Cleese commentary for each episode. Since we know the series so well that we can practically quote the dialogue as we view it, we have been watching the episodes with the Cleese commentary running. He shares some fascinating bits of information about the actors, the sets, the direction, and the background. Every time I hear him admire the young Connie Booth (his first wife, I guess!) I get the giggles!
John Cleese is one of the funniest men to walk this earth and it shows in this series. I've watched it since I was a little girl and it has became a holiday favorite. "Basil the Rat" is my Favorite.

I'm not someone who would watch anything twice, but somehow I've watched this three times (and counting) and also bought it for friends because everybody should own this great classic.
It's just wrong to go on living without seeing this.
Fawlty Towers - If you are a John Cleese fan - you won't stop laughing....Basel

Fawlty Towers is possibly the single greatest sitcom in the history of television. 12 legendary episodes about a british hotel and the cranky cantankerous owners. This is some of the funniest stuff I have ever seen, I was rolling on the floor laughing. John Cleese is absolutely brilliant! Great set, remastered - highly recommended for fans and non-fans alike!
This item met my expectations. I love British comedy and want good quality so that it'll last for many years of enjoyment.
Great series, Great DVD. I sure am glad I have this in my collection. Cleese is hysterical!

This box set contains all of the episodes of the original BBC series. I don't care how many times you watch these, they are pure comic genius and this set is an excellent entertainment value. Watching these at home allows the viewer to catch more of the comic subtleties in the show(like the hotel sign at the beginning of the show). There is a kind of chemistry between the cast members of this show that is unique only to Fawlty Towers. The extras included in this set are some bios on the cast and some little known facts about the series.

John Cleese and Connie Booth teamed up to create a comedy masterpiece.

The characters are richly farcical yet based on some really quirky folks.  The bonus materials flush out this information.

These programs are funny beyond belief, fast paced and a joy from start to finish.

Be warned, you will laugh.  A lot.

The writing is so good and the physical humor is so over the top.  "The Germans" stands out in my mind, but every episode has a little gem, like:  "Now Mr Fawltey, don't do anything we wouldn't do.  Oh. surely ladies, a little breathing." or "Never mind him, he's from Barcelona."

A really great show.
This is a favorite for my husband and daughter ... great to have it available on DVD to replace the old VHS set.

English comedy - you gotta love it.  This remastered edition is worth the purchase price it you were ever an afficianado.  I remember trying to watch it on our PBS station with its poor antenna reception...so this is pure fun, or pure funny.  Especially if you are a John Cleese fan.
If you like to laugh, this is a must for your collection.  Can't go wrong with John Cleese.

I LOVE Fawlty Towers...LOVE IT.  But I've had issue with this particular collection not working in my DVD player.  In the final episode of disc 1 "The Germans" the screen freezes as soon as the setting changes from the hospital to the hotel.

If you like British humor, if you like John Cleese, and if you like Monty Python humor, then you will understand the humor in this DVD. John Cleese runs a hotel, his wife abhors him and thinks he's a ninny, and the hired help for the hotel are hopelessly inept. A basis for most of us to be able to relate to Basil (who unfortunately actually is incompetent), the poor guy played by John Cleese, and that role is not quite as squeamish as John Lithgow is in 3rd Rock From The Sun, but along the same kind of humor. Prunella Scales is hilarious as an overbearing conceited British woman (the wife in the series), and the irreverent humor clashing in political incorrectness with German stereotypes who happen to be staying at the hotel is wonderful. Researching the hotel a bit by Googling "Fawlty Towers" gives you a marvelous insight on how this BBC TV series was based upon a real hotel, and the main character by John Cleese was inspired by a real person who was delightfully rude and boorish, as well as being a little bit nuts. The story's intentional complications and accidental misfires make this a very enjoyable farce about owning a hotel and trying to annoy people as much or more than they do you. I love this series, and first owned the series on VHS. Buy this DVD, you'll love it enough to want to keep watching and keep watching and keep watching until you've seen them all, and then start over again to see them over and over.  I recommend this highly to anybody with a love of British humor and even if you're just tired of being thought of as a boob in your own reality. Fun and entertaining without a doubt.

I have been a long time fan of Fawlty Towers since discovering it on PBS. I have been wanting to get a complete DVD set to replace my copies made from TV on VHS. This a great set with all of the episodes made and the extras are an additional pleasure to watch. Repeated viewings are just as funny as the first time seen.
Definitely have enjoyed reliving those laughs over the Fawlty Towers programs.  Glad that I was able to get it at such a good price as well.

This British Comedy Series has to be on everyone's list of "favorites" and/or "best"  program lists.  I know it's on mine.

The only bad things are that there are only 20 episodes and that John Cleese is now suffering from the results of the physical pratfalls he performed in the series.  Watching him perform was (and still is) magic.  Even his "fist waving" could bring hoots and hollars to the most sedate viewer. I always slipped into Pampers before watching the show, if you get my meaning.

It's comedy was way ahead of it's time.  Modernized to todays surroundings, it would rival anything on television for writing and character development.  The one problem would be in casting.  The original cast made the perfect ensemble.  I can't imagine who could fill the shoes of the original cast members.

I enjoyed every minute...

What can I say? This is one of the greatest and most thought-out shows of all time. Cleese seems to be clearly influenced by comic greats such as Ernie Kovacs and this is a good thing. Not to take anything away from Cleese, of course. Sadly, this show could not be made today, as it would be considered Politically Incorrect. So, folks, get it while you can, as its likely to be banned by the USA government soon. To quantify out of a 0-10 rating, I would give this brilliant series a "10." I just wished they'd have made more episodes. Purchase this set and you won't ever regret it. It is truly genius.

In addition to the new commentary and special features included in this set (mentioned in other reviews), I also wanted to note that I found the DVD remastering is somewhat better than that in the Fawlty Towers - The Complete Series set, which I also owned and watched several times. And if you're still watching FT on VHS, you really must upgrade! The colors and sharpness look like a live broadcast. There are 6 episodes on each of 2 discs, and each of these include 2 alternate commentaries to choose from (each series' director or Cleese), in addition to the normal mono audio track. A third disc contains interviews and a couple of other features which are well-documented in other reviews or in the item description here on Amazon. I was glad to see the extended interviews, as the 'Complete' set seemed to have less interview content from the other actors than this 'Remastered' set. The top menu animations and artwork are also inspired -- BBC did a good job of this, and I wish other DVD labels would invest a little more in their products this way. The beginning of each disc does have a couple of long leaders of information which you have to "next chapter" through if you don't want to see it, because the "menu" button will not otherwise take you to the menu until you've been forced to watch it. If you already have the previous 'Complete Series' set mentioned above and are wondering if it's worth upgrading, I think real Fawlty fans have to, just for the extra special feature content alone. If you ware just looking a good DVD version of the 12 episodes, either version would probably suffice, although this latest version currently seems to be less expensive when purchased new. I cannot help wondering if BBC did this remaster to also prepare for a blu-ray version one day (or some such HD standard), but for the $26 Amazon price when I ordered, it just didn't seem worth waiting for any potential HD release. Oh, and did I mention this is probably (arguably) the best television sitcom ever devised?

As funny as I remembered - not a weak episode in the lot.  TV's all-time greatest sitcom!  One annoying thing:  Each DVD has a beginning blurb hyping various British comedy series, that can't be bypassed.  At least Fast Forward works...
If your concerned about being PC don't buy this. That is why it's so funny. Worth seeing again and again.

Fawlty Towers is hilarious. Our family has watched it over and over again for years.
I will have to buy this new remastered collection.

When Fawlty Towers started appearing on DVD a few years ago I was keen to replace my old VHS tapes, though something convinced me not to buy the boxed set that I saw in the shops. I'm so pleased I held off.

The quality of Fawlty Towers Remastered is excellent. There are extra interviews, a short item about Torquay and the Gleneagles Hotel and Donald Sinclair from which the show was inspired, and I especially love watching with the John Cleese commentary running. He gives the viewer so much insight into how the shows came together, who the actors were, why jokes worked or didn't work and plenty of other tidbits that are so fascinating to anyone who loves this show. I already know the scripts virtually word for word so John's commentary alone is well worth the investment. So pleased I bought it. Congratulations to John Cleese, Connie Booth et al for making this the most popular British sitcom ever.
This was awesome! John Cleese at his best!! I love Monty Python and now I love Fawlty Towers!!

even after repeated viewings.
this was a gift for a relative in his eighties. He had never seen it before. He laughed until tears came into his eyes and his stomach hurt.

I understand John Cleese and Connie Booth wrote this series as well as acted in them. This is good comedy if you enjoy laughing. This is another one I wished would have had a longer run thus more episodes.

Say hello to Fawlty Towers: The Complete Collection Remastered! This newly-remastered collection of the classic BBC comedy series will have you laughing like almost nothing else!

I'd had surprisingly little exposure to Fawlty Towers until fairly recently. Back when I was a wee lad I remember seeing about two episodes of the show. Lately I've seen a heck of a lot more and found it to be one of the best, most consistently funny shows ever made!

The series follows the lives of people staying and working in Fawlty Towers, what is possibly the worst hotel in all of England. It's located on the British coast where, it turns out, people actually voluntarily go for vacations during the summer (having swam in the Pacific Ocean in an area just about as far north as Southern England, I think they're quite mad). The hotel is run by the impossible-to-deal-with Basil Fawlty (John Cleese). With him are his long-suffering wife, longer-suffering maid and even longer-suffering Spanish bellhop, the scene stealing Manuel (Andrew Sachs).

The plots tend to be very simple, and occasionally reveal a great deal about the age of the show (it was made in 1975 and 1979), but the execution is genius. The comic timing on display is incredible, particularly that of Sachs and Cleese.

This newly remastered version of the show contains all twelve episodes (12?! That's it?! Not a lot, I know, but the recent great shows The Office and Extras also only have twelve standard episodes each), of the show. You also get a whole raft of extra features, including commentaries, interviews, outtakes, a little booklet and even a Torquay Tourist Guide! Nice!

This is a very funny show and a heck of a good deal. I can't possibly praise it enough. Go pick it up!

Having purchased the previous Fawlty Towers complete series on DVD set three years ago, I was skeptical as to whether the "Remastered" version was worth it.  I can assure you that it is.  John Cleese's hilarious and insightful commentary alone is worth the extra investment.  As well, the sound and picture quality are noticeably better, adding to the enjoyment.  Highly recommended even if you have previously purchased the series on VHS or DVD.  Enjoy!

Aargh! I owned the VHS versions for years and finally broke down and bought the previous overpriced DVD edition last year. Now they've come out with a superior edition which is also cheaper!  I'll have to buy it for the Cleese commentaries alone. If you don't own these programs already then you've come along at the right time. This will be the best money you've spent in quite a while. This is one of the classic sitcoms of all time. Each meticulously crafted episode is so crammed with hilarious lines and situations that when you recall it later you won't believe that so many things happened in one half-hour show.  Cleese was really the first to put such an unpleasant character at the center of a sitcom. It would be tried again with the sadly brief 'Buffalo Bill' and with more success with 'Curb Your Enthusiasm'. Like Larry David, even when Basil Fawlty is right, he's wrong.

By far the best thing ever on television!  This is one series that I have watched, re-watched, and quoted for years!  It never gets old!  A must-own collection!

[...]

Having been a huge fan of this series since it first ran on PBS, I bought all the episodes years ago on VHS.  Hadn't gotten around to getting the DVD's, and now glad I waited for this special edition set.  I can highly recommend purchasing, even if you've never had the pleasure of viewing this comic classic before.  Sadly, only twelve episodes were made, but each one is pure gold, and infinitely superior to most sitcoms that run for years.  Can't wait to see all the extras.  The writing is genius; the cast is flawless--I could go on forever.  Thank you, John Cleese!

This post-Python series was created, written by and stars John Cleese and his ex-wife Connie Booth. Nearly every one of the 12 episodes here is a classic, chuck full of memorable lines and hilarious situations. Easily one of the funniest TV shows to come out of England or America. And this new version contains comments on every episode by Cleese himself. Buy it and prepare to laugh your arse off.

If you want to see a human being utterly debased in every episode by his wife and everyone else who he comes in contact with, than this is for you. I find watching this show the antithesis of comedy. Its nihilistic outlook is totally depressing.

I knew this was great before I purchased it; I'm just glad to get the complete series, short though it is, in one shot.  I'm introducing my 13-year-old to English humor and might as well start with the best of the best.  Well worth the money.

Really enjoy seeing these episodes again, uncut and with all of them available.  Although we've (in our household) loved Fawlty Towers from the first time we saw it on PBS years ago, we don't remember seeing the first season until now.  Thoroughly enjoying this DVD set.  Highly recommend.  John Cleese is absolutely hilarious, and the rest of the cast is superb also.
Fawlty Towers is as I remember it from the PBS run in the 80's.  One of the funniest shows ever.  John Cleese is a genius, furiously funny.

This series definitely stands the test of time! John Cleese ia as funny as ever and is supported by a wonderful cast including the brilliant Prunella Scales as his wife. The basic premise is John Cleese playing the pompous owner of a small seaside bed and breakfast in Torquy. His overbearing and arrogant attitude set up the classic interactions between staff and guests,while his long-suffering wife tries to mitigate the results of his folly.
The only birthday gift my husband liked. We enjoy watching this series, it is very very funny.

Sadly, discs 1 and 2, although labeled as different discs, had the same episodes on them.  As a result, many of the promised episodes were missing.  This was not the vendors fault since the discs themselves were clearly labeled as "1" and "2", but an error on the part of the BBC production department.
If you like British humor, you'll LOVE this sreies. John Cleese is remarkably hilarious....as he always is. I recommend this to anybody who needs a good laugh. Guareteed not to disappoint!!

Always a fan of John Cleese, this short series does not fail to provide hours of fun.  An excellent cast who work off each other like a finely tuned machine.  Even my wife who doesn't watch a lot of TV loves the show. You will not be disappointed.

Whenever I am up for some good laughs, I put in one of the Fawlty Towers DVDs.  It takes away your worries because it is just one laugh after another.  Our whole family enjoys it.  Each character has it's own unique place in the show.  They are all great.  Love it.

Hoping to "upgrade" from my VHS Fawlty to DVD, I ordered the complete DVD series. Unfortunately, the set I received was defective. The disks were marked v. 1, 2 and 3, but the set actually contained TWO v. 2s, ONE v. 3 and NO v. 1. I requested a replacement for this set, and received another DEFECTIVE set identical to the above. I will be returning both sets and asking for a refund as I don't trust that I will ever receive a complete, perfect set. This series is truly one of the greats of BritCom-Dom and deserves 5+ stars, but my experience with the product quality is quite disappointing. Sybil would certainly never stand for it...

This is the perfect set. It has all the episodes as aired.
It also has extras such as outtakes, interviews and I believe voice-overs on sound track 2 from the producers/directors. You will NOT be disappointed with this set.

As with The thin Blue line there is only 12 episodes, but I would rather have 12 great episodes like these, than more episodes that are hit and miss.  I can watch them over and over --- and I do!

Jim

Just buy it and you'll see what real British humor is all about.
'cause you can't stop laughing. it is the entire volume of Family Towers the best British watched sitcom in Holland.

I had to permanently donate my original DVD set of Flatery Owls to a friend who, incredibly, had never seen the series, despite her self-professed love for British comedy.  She had heard of Benny Hill, Dave Allen, On The Buses, Are You Being Served, etc.  In a sense, however, I could sort of understand why.  As other reviewers have said, this is a unique series, and due to it's painfully short 12-episode duration, is not aired in the same way as others.  Here in the US, for example, it's usually shown in sequence during a one-day PBS pledge-drive.  If that's not how she watched TV, then she might indeed miss it.  But the comedy style of insults, slapstick, wittiness, double-entendres, etc, are not quite like other British sitcoms, or Monty Python or anything really:  it's a style of comedy all its own.  The closest style I might compare it too is some of the best, live-action plays I've seen, although not too many people see plays these days.  But I think it's a mistake to try to deconstruct Fawlty Towers too much in order to see what makes it so funny, because I find it ruins the fun and spontaneity.  For me, this series is simply the benchmark for the very best comedy writing I have seen, and I can watch it every year and thoroughly enjoy it (which maybe speaks little for me).  I liked Fawlty Towers as a youngster and I still like it now, even though my taste in TV and writing has changed vastly over 30 years.

The set has several interesting interviews from the principal actors included, and compared to many modern DVD's it might provide more extras in this way, although I found myself wanting a little more than what was included.  At the time, however, I had paid $64.99 USD, while as of today, the set currently sells for around $24.  The transfer is good -- it's not HDTV, but images are crisp and colors very good, as is the sound.  If you grew up watching this on analog TV or video cassettes, it's quite a step up.  Certain fashion styles aside, the series certainly does not look it's age.  Although it might be overkill, I am hoping BBC might still consider a 1080p version of the set one day.

Other reviews thoroughly-describe the content and pretext of the episodes.  I will only add that, if by some chance you are one of those who haven't seen Fawlty Towers yet, and enjoy comedy to any degree, you really must see this.  It's been 35 years since the first 6 episodes were made, yet I still occasionally hear people I don't know quote lines from the show...usually insults...a testament to the lasting effect the show has upon those who've seen it.  And the next time you hear someone order a Lemon Squash, or tell someone to stop talking about the war, you'll understand at least one more reason why people within earshot might start snickering.

Nothing really needs to be said about this classic British sitcom, except that it contains some of the most brilliant, most hilarious, and most humiliatingly ghastly moments in the entire history of television.

And "Fawlty Towers Complete Collection" brings together the entire series in all its embarrassing avalanchal glory. It's one of those universally funny TV shows, all about the undignified exploits of a perpetually hostile, repressed and tetchy hotel manager, and the more competant staff who try to keep thngs sane, written with demented zeal ("That's Brahms! Brahms' Third Racket!") and excellent comic acting.

Basil (John Cleese) and Sybil Fawlty (Prunella Scales) run a moderately-sized hotel in Torquay, with the assistance of the clever waittress Polly (Connie Booth) and the Spanish waiter Manuel (Andrew Sachs) whose grasp of English is a work in progress. The hotel is home to a dotty old soldier, fluttery spinsters, and a revolving door of very dissatisfied customers.

Basil Fawlty (Cleese) puts out a snotty ad to attract a "better class of customer," which attracts a pleasant aristocrat. Basil fawns revoltingly over the man, neglecting the other guests. But savvy waittress Polly (Connie Booth) discovers that another guest (who Basil snubs because he's Cockney) is a member of the CID -- and that Basil is in danger of handing his valuable coins over to a con man.

And it's not the last disaster that Basil only manages to make much worse: an inept gang of builders are called in while Sybil is away; a bunch of couples seem to be cheating on one another; four Germans arrive at the hotel just in time for Basil to suffer a brain-scrambling head injury; a deaf woman causes general hotel mayhem; and the creme-de-la-creme of Torquay society arrive for a "Goumet Night," just in time for the chef to get drunk after Manuel rejects his advances. Hilarity (and roast ducks) ensue.

An American tourist who demands a Waldorf salad -- after the cook leaves for the day -- ends up tangled in Basil's web of lies; an overnight guest expires in bed, leading to a frantic cover-up; an anniversary party is wrecked when Sybil storms out just as the guests arrive. And after a health inspector condemns Fawlty Towers, Basil discovers that Manuel has a pet rat ("Is Siberian hamster -- a filagree!") -- which is soon running wild through the hotel.

Anyone who's sick of the recycled sitcoms ("Hot Young Urbanites Fall In Love and Have Misadventures") that pepper the TV landscape every single season might want to try "Fawlty Towers" -- the humour is still fresh, the writing is hilarious ("If the guest isn't singing 'Oh What a Beautiful Morning,' I don't immediately think 'Oh, there's another snuffed it in the night'"), and the actors were great at physical comedy.

Basically every episode is about a bad situation that Basil makes infinitely worse, until the entire episode is a landslide of lies, offenses and disasters. Each episode is full of gags (Basil strangling the gnome), misunderstandings ("There's a kipper sticking out of your vest"), and plots that revolve mainly around Basil's increasingly frantic efforts to keep everything "normal." Everything gets crazier as the episodes wind on.

And Cleese's writing is typically brilliant here -- Basil gets most of the great lines ("Always reminds me of somebody machine-gunning a seal"") but there are some glorious bits of dialogue from others ("Will you stop talking about the war?" "Me? You started it!" "We did not start it!" "Yes you did -- you invaded Poland!").

Cleese plays Basil as a slightly deranged, high-strung, incompetent guy who treats his customers like so many itchy spots, and Prunella Scales serves as the more competent, vaguely contemptuous counterpoint to him. Connie Booth's Polly is the only truly smart and clever person in the entire hotel, and usually gets sucked into Basil's freaky schemes ("Flying Tart!"); and Andrew Sachs is rather cute and sweet as the much-abused Manuel, whose half-learned English provides quite a bit of humor ("I am from Barcelona!").

The new edition may be worth the dip for fanatical Fawlty fans -- apparently the entire series is being restored. Additionally, Cleese has gone back to record commentaries for ALL the episodes, and there are interviews with everybody in the main cast. Sounds like it's going to be good.

"Fawlty Towers Complete Collection"  is one of those shows that shone brightly and briefly, like a fireworks display. Hilarious, uproarious, and utterly timeless.
this is the funniest series I have ever seen..a great cast including john cleese,connie booth.prunella scales

Timing is everything in comedy and no one seems to understand that better than John Cleese playing Basil Fawlty, who runs with his wife perhaps the worst Inn in the British Isles.  Everyone else is the straight man to Cleese in this uproarious series.  If Basil Fawlty thinks you are an English lord staying in his Inn, he is all boot licking, fawning obnoxiousness personified.  He literally falls all over the lord as he is a genius at taking a pratfall.  If he thinks you are a lower class nobody muscling in on his Inn, he is totally obnoxious as the worst sort of English snob, nose in the air. He does his best to ignore you and if you can't be ignored, he delivers devastating put downs, one-liners which are classics in the genre.  You are just as likely to find Fawlty pawing through some guest's room (and about to be caught) as you are to find him skulking in the office trying to avoid front desk duties or making mayhem in the dining room, usually trying to favor one diner over another with his snobbish judgments.

Prunella Scales delivers the voice of reason, his wife, flawlessly.  Manuel, the barely English speaking bellhop is a bit reminiscent of Roberto Benigni in his most comic roles.  Polly the maid is a co-writer with Cleese of the show. She is so convincing as a maid that it is hard to believe she is a brilliant writer in real life.

But Cleese is the star all the way and I've always been sad there were only 12 episodes.  The classic British idea of a series is always much shorter than the American idea of a series on tv.

Too bad, there are only 12 episodes of Fawlty Towers. There should have dozens of episodes. While there is talk of a remake, nobody could touch this cast featuring the genius and unknighted John Cleese who probably won't be knighted by the Queen after all. His character, Basil Fawlty, would be appalled by John Cleese's statements about their native Britain. Basil Fawlty runs a small bed and breakfast called Fawlty Towers with his long-time wife, Sybil Fawlty, played by the brilliant Prunella Scales CBE. She could become the next Dame Commander of the Order of the British Empire and probably will and hopefully or Lady West if her husband, Timothy West CBE, gets knighted. Cleese's wife, who plays Polly, an aspiring artist, was American born and raised Connie Booth who has become a therapist in London, England and has given up acting. Andrew Sachs plays the always funny Manuel who is from Barcelona and often the subject of Basil's anger and abuse. Poor Manuel, Sachs does him brilliantly. There are supporting characters like the two old senior ladies who are permanent residents and the late funny Berkeley Ballard as a retired military man. Fawlty Towers takes place in Torquay, a seaside town in Southern Britain. As one guest jokes about the lack of sights have been reduced to a page or a brochure.

Every episode is brilliantly mastered to fit the right effects of the audience which is constant laughter no matter how silly the circumstances or bizarre. I wished John Cleese well and I can't imagine anything that could replace Fawlty Towers. He gave us this brilliance only leaving us wanting so much more. It's hard to imagine that British sitcoms have a 6 episode season in comparison to American sitcoms where they can range from 14-22 episodes and that is recently. I loved watching guests like Geoffrey Palmer OBE and others in these episodes.

Nothing really needs to be said about the classic British sitcom "Fawlty Towers," except that the third and final collection of episodes contains some of the series' most brilliant, most hilarious, and most humiliatingly ghastly moments. "Fawlty Towers - Waldorf Salad/The Kipper and the Corpse/The Anniversary/Basil the Rat" sends abusive hotelier Basil Fawlty through his last round of demented crises, and it's more fun than ever.

Basil's insensitivity and overambition finally get the best of him when he tries to cater to a wealthy, equally obnoxious American tourist who wants a Waldorf salad. The result: a crazy scheme in which Basil tries to pretend that the cook hasn't left for the day, and cobble together a foodstuff that he doesn't know the first thing about. And it turns out that the American isn't the only unsatisfied customer.

Then when an overnight guest expires in bed, Basil is thrown into a frenzy -- first he thinks it's because of some expired kippers he served the dead man (when he was already dead), and then he's determined to keep the death secret from all the other guests. Unfortunately, there aren't many places in a hotel that you can hide a dead body where someone won't stumble across it -- and Basil spreads the usual chaos as he and the staff stuff it in wardrobes, bedrooms and the office.

When Basil and Sybil's twentieth anniversary rolls around, Basil secretly plans a party with some old friends of theirs. Unfortunately Sybil thinks he really HAS forgotten their anniversary, and storms off just as the friends arrive -- and a frantic Basil tries to convince the other couples that Sybil's got a weird mystery illness and has NOT left him. Unfortunately, they're too determined to see her, resulting in a very weird masquerade for Polly.

And the series finale deals with what restaurants dread most: a health inspector, who deems the kitchen unsafe and unfit. While everyone tries to get the hotel shipshape, Basil discovers that Manuel has a pet rat ("Is Siberian hamster -- a filagree!") in his room and orders it to be somehow removed from the premises. Unfortunately little Basil The Rat finds his way back into the hotel... at the same time that the health inspector returns to Fawlty Towers.

"Fawlty Towers" is one of those shows that shone brightly and briefly, like a fireworks display -- the last four episodes of the series show little signs of slowing comic genius, and it leaves you wistfully wishing that John Cleese and Co. had managed to turn out one more season. As it is, the series ended on a high note without the jokes getting tired or old.

"Waldorf Salad" is perhaps the weakest of these episodes, since it stretches the Basil-tries-to-pretend-the-cook-is-still-there joke to the max. But the other three are absolutely hilarious mixes of gags (the rat-in-the-purse scene), misunderstandings ("There's a kipper sticking out of your vest"), and plots that revolve mainly around Basil's increasingly frantic efforts to keep everything "normal." Everything gets crazier as the episodes wind on.

And Cleese's writing is typically brilliant here -- Basil gets most of the great lines ("Look, I'm just delivering a tray, right. If the guest isn't singing 'Oh What a Beautiful Morning,' I don't immediately think 'Oh, there's another snuffed it in the night'") but there are some glorious bits of dialogue from others ("Don't talk to anyone, but he's dead." "Ah. Shot, was he?" "No, no. He died in his sleep." "In his sleep? Well, you're off your guard, you see").

Cleese continued to play Basil as a slightly deranged, high-strung, incompetent guy who finally gets told off en masse in "Waldorf Salad," and Prunella Scales serves as the more competent, vaguely contemptuous counterpoint to him. Connie Booth's Polly finally gets sick of Basil's weird ideas in "Anniversary" and has to be bribed into impersonating Sybil, while Andrew Sachs has a rather cute scene in the final episode where he threatens to leave if they get rid of his pet rat.

Wave a tearful farewell to "Fawlty Towers" in its third collection of episodes... then go eat a Waldorf salad and some overripe kippers on your anniversary, and shoot at some rats.

What a feast for all admirers of good comedy, English humor, British sitcoms, and John Cleese. God bless him and his wife at the time and collaborator Connie Booth for brilliant flawless writing of twelve (sadly, only twelve) 30 minutes episodes and to all cast for starring in the series that went on to become the top on the list of the 100 Greatest British Television Programs drawn up by the British Film Institute in 2000. Having watched all twelve episodes during last weekend, I see very clearly where my favorite comedy of all times, A Fish Called Wanda swam from. Some episodes of Fawlty Towers are simply perfect or very close to being perfect. All twelve are always funny, crazy, hilarious and never ever for a second are boring or outdated despite been made over 30 years ago. Cleese is fabulous participating in almost every scene of the show and playing rude, cheap, obnoxious, and incompetent owner of the Seaside hotel in "English Riviera" which he manages along with domineering, and much more confident wife Sybil (Prunella Scales). With all these characteristics, Cleese manages to make Basil Fawlty somehow sympathetic in this never ending escalation of comical frustration. The point is - the show is absolutely hilarious without ever stooping to vulgarity or stupidity. It is a highest class entertainment and I am happy that I finally was able to enjoy all 12 episodes. The show was transferred beautifully to 3 DVD Set which IMO is one of the best sets I've had pleasure to experience. Each of three DVDs comes with the nice bonus features that include among many three parts interview with John Cleese who tells in great details about the origins of the show, its production, and how much fun it was for everyone involved. Cleese recalls visiting a hotel similar to Fawlty Towers during the filming of Monty Python  series.  The hotel manager whom Cleese describes as "He was so rude, he was wonderful" had become an inspiration for Basil Fawlty. The interview with Prunella Scales and Andrew Sacks who was as hilarious as Cleese playing Spanish waiter/porter Manuel ("You'll have to forgive him. He is from Barcelona") with very limited command in English also add to the great feast that Fawlty Towers has been since its original showing in the 70s. The best episode, IMO is Communication Problems which is absolute perfection. It introduces us to the "guest from hell" in the body of Mrs. Richards, a very demanding lady with the hearing problems and the hearing aid that she would use quite selectively. Along with this guest, Basil Fawlty has to deal with the old passion for horses betting, the avenue of pleasure that is completely closed by his bossy wife Sybil. The result is the funniest and best acting episode of all - thanks to the regular players and late Joan Sanderson who almost stole the show as Mrs. Richards. The single most hilarious scene in all episodes definitely is the one in the episode "Germans" and it has to do with a talking moose head. I've returned to it several times while watching the episode and the scene always brought the tears from laughing too hard. To make the long story short - watch Fawlty Towers. It's got the top position on the list of 100 Best British TV programs for very good reasons and totally deserves it. It is one of the best and funniest sitcoms ever in the TV history.

If I have to pick the most distinguishing characteristic for Fawlty Towers, it would be that it is the funniest comedy I have seen. You can watch it many times over the years and every time you will have tears from laughing, and for days after you will be wearing a smile, with an occasional burst of laughter, to the dismay of those around you.
The show has been crafted with great attention to detail in the writing, the scenes, the filming, and does not resort to vulgarity or profanity. But beyond that, it is one of those rare, magic accomplishments that happens once in a great while, and cannot be duplicated.
Much has been written about the show, some of which I find surprising. For example, it has nothing in common with the Three Stooges. The occasional poke, or slap is in entirely different context. It usually is the culmination of a long string of frustrations. The show also has nothing in common with Monty Python, other than John Gleese is in both.
Fawlty Towers holds a preeminent position in our comedy collection.
Amazon also gets 5 stars for the entire shopping experience.

Fawltly Towers is still just as funny today as it was when it came on air years ago.  Anyone who runs or has spent a night or two at a bed & breakfast will really relate on many levels.  It's just plain good ol' humor and is John Cleese at his best!!

I bought this for my brother for Christmas. We're both fans of the show and we watched each episode right away. Each one is hilarious! Honestly, they're all great. Too bad they only did a dozen episodes.
Hilarious classic. This was a replacement for our old worn out video tape version.  Quality is much improved from the tape version. Many details that we couldn't see before. Kids love it too.

If you enjoy John Cleese and English humor, this is a wonderful set. I recalled watching a few shows 25 years ago and then learned I could buy the entire set. My wife and I have thoroughly enjoyed the shows -- lots of laughs!!

My DVD collection arrived in a timely manner and was in great condition!  It's an early birthday gift for my husband and he's totally happy with my selection!!  Thank you for the always great service from Amazon.com!

What is so great about FT is how psychologically acute it is. The relation between Basil and Sybil is fantastic. You can see how ten years earlier they both might have seen each other as quite a catch. She, pretty and vivacious. He, tall and from a slightly higher social class They are sort of lower middle class and middle middle class respectively. Unfortunately, they have basically incompatible tastes and interests and the resulting marriage can perhaps best be described as toxic, as they make their own private hell for each other. Totally believable.

These products were originally enjoyed on ordinary television 30-40 years ago without the technology avalalble today.  Does that make them less entertaining NOW? NO - I think not, fools, look past your spoiled digital minds.  If you can't enjoy them without nitpicking over "artifacts", etc. - TOUGH.  I'm just thrilled we still have access to them.  You should be too.

Being a Python fan and a fan of some other British comedies (Good Neighbors, Are You Being Served), I was very pleased to find this complete DVD set at a used store that I shop at. Once I got it home and started watching, however, it was very clear that this type of comedy was made for people with certain tolerances. Fawlty Towers fans, I expect to get flamed for this, so flame away. The criticism I will try to make is going to be based on logic, not rants.
  First, the main character, Basil Fawlty, played by Cleese. Basil was modeled after an experience Cleese and the other Pythons had with an extremeely foul-tempered hotel owner while on holiday. Basil is brash, rude, inconsiderate, and generally painful to watch. He is a complete and utter wanker to his guests unless they are of some high social standing. Once in a while, we see Basil get his comeuppance from an overly irritated guest, or something of the like, and that's actually enjoyable, as he usually gets thumped pretty severely. Every person at one time or another has wanted to do that to someone as utterly nasty as Basil.
 Comedian Richard Briers said in his interview on the 'Good Neighbors' series that to be a comedy actor you had to exude a certain amount of vulnerability so that the the audience would care about you. Cleese's character of Basil evokes no sympathy or empathy whatsoever, as you find it impossible to relate to a man who is so deliberately narcissistic, sarcastic, and rude to his guests. Perhaps this is why John Cleese hates Britain so much, for those few individuals who are so class-conscious that they constantly trod on other people.
  Secondly, the cast. There does not seem to be any chemistry between most of the leading actors, and most of the acting seems forced, not to mention the gags. The only saving grace is Manuel the waiter, played by Andrew Sachs. There is a lot of byplay involving his difficulty communicating with the customers (and Basil) because of his difficulty learning the language.
  This series was one that I really wanted to like, and it fell very short .It's a shame they only made four seasons of Good Neighbors, as it was a fine Britcom. Perhaps I'll try 'Yes, Minister' next.
As with all things I order on "Amazon.com", I received the DVDs earlier than anticipated.  I was very pleased.  In fact, I just ordered MORE DVDs from Amazon.com yesterday.
If Fawlty Towers doesn't make you laugh nothing will. One of the greatest series of all time.
My husband had recorded this series onto VHS tape years earlier.  I jumped at the chance to get it for him on DVD.

Although my wife and I saw these sketches 100 years ago, the first four we have watched this week gave us so much laughter to protect us from the anguish on the news' broadcasts. Too bad there were only 12 skefches created by John Cleese.

Faulty Towers is humor at its very best.  This video series features British actor/comedian John Cleese,who not only writes the material, but is the lead character, "Mr. Faulty".  He and his wife, Sybil, own a bed and breakfast in England.  The stories revolve around them and their servant "Manuel" (a native of Barcelona, who is learning English), their housekeeper/waitress, Polly, and permanent resident called "the Major" and the various guests who stay in the Inn, which is named Faulty Towers.  We have watched this series over and over and it's just as funny the last time as the first time.  We have found that this series is a wonderful gift and highly recommend it.  First class comedy !!

I cannot imagine a world without Basil Fawlty.
I have always been a fan of all things Monty Python, but John Cleese emerged as my favorite.  (If you've never seen Clockwise, give it a viewing.)
Anyway, Basil is the patron saint of all the put-upon, the cranky, the snobbish nobodies who are completely unable to rise to the occasion, any occasion, and behave themselves. We love Basil, the bitter and impatient proprietor of a little hotel in a British resort town, and his inexplicably loyal employees Polly and Manuel and his long-suffering wife, and the absurd situations they get themselves into and (try) to get themselves out of.  Many of the punchlines have become stock phrases around our house.
We are still nursing along the old VHS tapes.  I bought the DVDs as a gift, and it looks as though they have some interesting extras.
I replaced my video copies with the dvd because I love this series so much I couldn't go without!

Fawlty Towers is a deliciously amusing series by comedic genius John Cleese. If you enjoy British Comedies such as Absolutely Fabulous or Keeping up Appearances, then you need to get this DVD set. John Cleese and all his supporting actors/actresses do an amazing job in this series.

A must have for anybody that loves John Cleese and/or British Comedies.

I hate Fawlty Towers, which is why I bought it for the family for Christmas.  Every episode makes me laugh until my abs feel like I've done about a thousand crunches.  This is good family entertainment that everyone can enjoy.
This series is John Cleese at his funniest. The episodes can be watched over and over again and still be funny even though you know the plotline

we bought the series for a christmas gift and just hope the recipient loves it. we have not been able to review it ourselfs.people i work with have raved about the series. so taking their opinion to heart, i purchased it hoping the recipient will enjoy it as well.

This review is prompted by a recent two-star review complaining that Fawlty Towers is "simply" a farce, is not thought-provoking, and is merely a solo vehicle for John Cleese as opposed to, per that reviewer, Monty Python movies.

To each his own, I guess.

This is far from a solo Cleese show. Each of the regulars is a unique, fully realized character. It is the interplay between these characters (with each other and with Cleese) that makes the show. Compare it to some other comedy shows that have a "star" comedian as a lead. For example, Mork and Mindy. That is an example of a "solo" effort and is quite the opposite of Fawlty Towers. You don't see any of the characters in FT standing around laughing at some Cleese antic and looking like they forgot their lines or missed their cue. In FT all the actors stay in character and are generally essential to the scene they are in.

It is agreed that this is not the place if you are looking for something "genuinely thought-provoking" (as that other reviewer wished for). But then again, neither are any of the Monty Python movies (despite that other reviewer's belief). So yes, FT is a farce, but farce is an honorable art form. Just ask William Shakespeare and Geoffrey Chaucer, for starters.

Fawlty Towers is one of the funniest, most tightly-scripted shows ever on TV. Some of the episodes are right up there with _The Comedy of Errors_ and _The Miller's Tale_. And I think the target audience for all of these was about the same.

Fawlty Towers is simply he best comedy ever written. I bought this collection for a friend in the Hotel/Resturant business, who never did see this show. I highly recommend for anyone, but it is a must see if you are in the Hotel/Resturant business.

My husband and I both love British humor. This was my husband pick for us. At first, it really irritated ME. When I was watching, I was telling  "that is enough!!!!!!". Thanks to my husband, I kept watching, after a while I found myself enjoying as much as my husband did. :). By the way, Fawlty Towers is the name of the little typical small hotel in England. The owners, husband and wife, are trying to do their best for their clients :))

All 12 episodes are of the best quality.  I watch it over and over again.

I am completely satisfied with this product and the shipping was fast and on time.

I reccommend this product to any John Cleese fan out there.

I give this product 5 stars and a Hearty Thank You to Amazon.com.

Much as I am loathe to start off with a cliche, cliches are cliches because they're true.

As many have said, Fawlty Towers is the single funniest TV series ever created. There's no argument, and no other series even comes close. It's like comparing the Beatles to other bands or Jimi Hendrix to other guitarists. Some artists just exist in their own singular dimension, and it's true of this show. What does one say, that it's the Mount Everest of television comedy? More like the rings of Saturn...

This masterpiece is given its proper honor in this fine box set, loaded with lengthy extras. The most surprising of these is the contemporary interview with Prunella Scales, revealing her to be a warm, charming and very sweet woman, which of course hammers home what a remarkable performance she gave in every episode of the show. And the same is true of the interview with Andrew Sachs, the immortal and incomparable Manuel.

Currently offered at a steep discount by Amazon, the price is in fact irrelevant. The set is worth twice, three times the cost, even if and perhaps especially if you've lived with the show since your youth. Every minute is just perfection, especially in terms of the writing, the quality of which is off the scale. And in every episode, episodes you may have seen dozens of times over the decades, there are countless laugh out loud scenes... even in cases where you know every line, where you anticipate every punch line, every fall, every double-take.

Most comedy doesn't bear up well to repeated playing but that's not the case here. Fawlty Towers is like a piece of great music, a classic album, in that its appeal never ends and in fact grows on the listener. It flourishes, it unfolds. In watching these episodes you see little things you never saw before, nuances of delivery that escaped you... and again, it's the writing... you relish every syllable, and if writing means something to you, you find yourself in awe of these scripts for there's not a line wasted.

I know, this review seems excessive in its praise, but I'll just end with the delicious fact that the British Film Institute named Fawlty Towers as the #1 Television Program of All Time.

Sheer unadulterated and relentless GENIUS.

Like all the Monty Python alumni, John Cleese is talented and funny.  From Monty Python (of course) to A Fish Called Wanda, Cleese always just makes me laugh.

And it is not different in Fawlty Towers, where he is at his acerbic and crazy best as the owner of a hotel where circumstances always leads to laughs, and Cleese is surrounded with other actos who do a great job.

Echos of Monty Pythin are here, plus other elements thrown in, so if you are a Python or Cleese Fan you will find the series hilarious. British style humor that works well for all and the extras do add to the set which makes it a wothwhile DVD set to have in your collection since the episodes, like all good comedy, can be watched more than once and still be worth it.

Fawlty Towers is one of those British sitcoms that although they haven't a high number of episodes, the quality alone is something to make it a timeless classic. I think the high number of people who wil gladly vouch for how good this sitcom is only expresses the true quality of the comedy and the cast involved. The characters are well defined and the setting is utilised to its full potential. Only 13 episodes were made but managed to gain such a cult following, those 13 episodes were just enough to keep the likes of Basil Fawlty a household name for over 30 years. Only the likes of Del Boy and Rodney have gained such a heightened level of comedic status.

The story is simple, Fawlty Towers is a hotel owned and managed by Basil Fawlty (John Cleese) and his wife sybil (Prunella Scales). Basil is supported by his hotel cleaner and waitress Polly (Connie Booth) and his bellboy and waiter Manuel (Andrew Sachs). The cast blend together brilliantly and have given us some of the funniest TV moments we're ever likely to see in our lifetime. Basil is the typical stressed out middle aged man, he goes on by letting lifes little troubles ware him down. He constantly tries to be the man about the hotel but constantly has his masculinity taken away from him by the scorn of Sybil.

John Cleese has always been a man I've considered as one of my idols, and this sitcom is the reason behind that. The comedy may be very slapstick, politically incorrect and at times very childish. I can't explain it but it all just seems to work in a way that will have you in fits of laughter no matter how many times you watch. The character of Basil is shockingly brilliant, I don't think anyone else could have played the character to such a level like John Cleese has. He is over the top, slick, stupid and physically funny. One of the best episodes that shows Cleese's physical prowess when playing this role is the infamous episode "The Germans" which spawned the line "Don't mention the war." The Hitler impression is something to be witnessed and regardless of whether you find things like that offensive or not, you just have to laugh.

Basil Fawlty is everything we find funny about people who lose their temper. He has his moments of trying to hide such terrible situations from his wife, but because of those attempts at hiding the problems he only manages to make them worse. The best example of this is when Sybil wants some building work done on the hotel, she wants to use a well respected but expensive builder. He wants to have a friend to do it on the cheap but he is anything but respectful. While Sybil is away for a weekend, Basil goes against her wishes and has his friend do it with disastrous consequences. What follows is a hysterical attempt at hiding the tragic building work from his wife by trying to keep her out of the hotel.

It's a fantastic series and I could honestly go on talking about it forever. I have nothing but good things to say about every cast member and their respective characters. John Cleese is a legend and he is one of a kind, he made the character his own and would have been something nobody else could have done. I would recommend this set to anyone with even a decent sense of humour.
After borrowing the set of discs several times we finally broke down and purchased a set of our own.  Several of the episodes are laugh out loud funny.

Fawlty Towers is definitely in the top 5 British comedies ever made.  It's based loosely on a real hotel manager in a hotel that John Cleese and the rest of the Monty Python team stayed at in the very real town of Torquay in South West England.  It's extremely funny and you'll never tire of it.  Classic scenes such as "The Germans", "Waldorf salad" and "Mr Fawlty, I know nothing" will have you howling out loud even if it is over 30 years old.  With all 12 episodes, this DVD is worth every cent.

Basil Fawlty (John Cleese) is far from a perfect man. In fact he's a terrible terrible person. But you end up overlooking that fact for the simple reason that he makes you laugh. Most of the scrapes he gets himself into would be easily taken care of if he could simply tell the truth. But that concept is foreign to him.

This series ran the perfect amount of time, ending while it was still hilarious. Each episode is a unique story, never retreading old ground. If you are a fan of the British use of both irony and farce, this is a virtual treasure trove of humor.

This show was and remains lightyears ahead of anything on American TV.  From start to finsih, it is sheer brilliance.  The ebtire case is hysterical and the chemistry between the characters is just obvious.  Who doesn't remember the Rat inspector episode?  How can one forget Mrs. Richards???? One of the funniest British Comedies of all times.  Delightful to watch.  Written with intelligence, this is a must have in any video collection.  I am always seeing something new and laughing out loud every time I put this DVD in the player to watch.

There are full descriptions of the episodes in other reviews. Fawlty Towers is one of the best comedy series ever produced. Every episode is composed of a number of story lines; each wrapping around the others. John Cleese said that he and Connie Booth would lay out a long roll of paper and write ideas across the length of it interweaving the ideas so that they all came together at the end into a very funny episode. The various characters are well crafted and each is at least a little insane. Cleese is a great physical actor (watch "The Germans" and "The Kipper and the Corpse").  I love David Kelley (Mr. O'Riley, the builder). He is a great character (you saw him in "Waking Ned Devine"). If you like great comedy, British or not, get this collection.  I'll bet you'll love it.

There is nothing I've ever seen as funny as these 12 episodes of Fawlty Towers.  So funny and clever that you can watch them over and over and still laugh out loud rolling on the floor! We always enjoyed watching Fawlty Towers when it was first released in Canada back in the late 70's.  Now we can watch it as often as we wish and have a good laugh.

In this spectacular BritCom, Monty Python's John Cleese stars as a disgruntled hotel owner named Basil Fawlty.  He cowrote the show with then-wife Connie Booth, who plays the maid, Polly Sherman.  Cleese and Booth divorced after Season 1, and it took a while 'til they could work together again to write and star in Season 2.  After that, they could not work together anymore, and it's a real shame that only 2 seasons of this brilliant comedy was ever made.  Prunella Scales plays Fawlty's wife, Sybill, a bit of a shrew who always has more important things to do than helping to run the hotel.  And Andrew Sachs plays the mousy Spanish bellhop, Manuel, who tries to be a good employee, but his efforts are hampered by the fact that he doesn't speak English.  Basil is short-tempered, rude to the guests, trying to raise the hotel's standards while remaining cheap and overall, unpleasant.  Guests range from brazen French women, obnoxious Americans, people who think their dogs are people, senile retired Army Majors, confidence tricksters, old ladies who complain about everything but refuse to turn on their hearing aids, and people who have the nerve to die in bed overnight.  Also they have to deal with hotel inspectors, drunken gay gourmet chefs, snobs, incompetent builders/construction workers and the health department...not to mention a psychiatrist, and even Germans!  Every episode is a classic!  This is truly one of the best and funniest sitcoms ever made anywhere on the planet!
HIGHLY RECOMMEND!
This is a great classic British Comidy from the 1970's.  I loved it then, and it is still as funny in 2008.
Have watched it for over 30 years on television.  I was sick of waiting for shows to appear on tv so I bought the set.

Don't take me seriously. They spend the entire series making fun of themselves and other nationalities. And it's hilarious.

And it's John Cleese. Fans of Monty Python will love this.

This is a very funny series, and this DVD set has all of the episodes of FAWLTY TOWERS : what more could anyone ask for? If you think John Cleese was funny in MONTY PYTHON'S FLYING CIRCUS you will probably enjoy him in FAWLTY TOWERS. All the other cast members are great as well.

Basil the Rat may be one of the finest pieces of british TV created since the parrott sketch from Monty Python ... this is a precious piece of british tv history .. I got so excited I bought two for friends as well

Very nicely packaged, sound and picture quality were excellent.  John Cleese's interview segments were a tad rambling, and the outtakes feature wasn't nearly long enough.  "Fawlty Towers" (or "Fatty Owls", "Farty Towels", "Flay Otters"...read the sign out front at the start of each episode) was wonderful in its time and it's wonderful now.  Basil Fawlty, it turns out, was based on a real hotelier -- imagine paying good money to go to a seaside resort and then being verbally abused by a hotel owner who loved the business, but hated people!  Ole Basil wasn't as far off the mark as he seemed!
One of the best comedy shows of all time.  Wish they'd do an updated version.

If you don't get the humor there is nothing I can say to convince you and won't try. Hilarity, social commentary, slapstick all rolled into one.  Farty Towels forever!

I remember going to a party a long time ago when the host gathered everyone into the family room to watch a video.  He told us you just have to see this.  It was the first episode of Fawlty Towers I ever saw.  I was hooked.  John Cleese is simply the funniest comedian EVER.  It's too bad they only made 12 of these.  Think of this as the Black Knight from Holy Grail versus his batty wife, hotel guests, and hotel staff in a rural hotel setting.  Hilarious from start to end, it's just the best comedy ever produced. "OH! It's my fault, is it?"
I previously owned this series on tape which I literally wore out! Cleese at his brilliantly funny best, and a must have for the collection of any Brit comedy devotee.

Fawlty Towers is still the funniest series ever produced.  The cast was perfect, the scripts crisp, action-packed and hilarious, and the situations were totally believable. John Cleese is a master of physical and verbal comedy, with the remarkable goose-step, the thrashing of the mini, the manhandling of Manuel, the spasmodic jerks and jumps - one can go on and on.  The rest of the cast is perfect and fantastics, but Cleese is the pivotal character in the mix.  His unctious, obsequiousness to those perceived to be in the upper class and drop-dead rudeness to everyone else is one of key elements of action at Fawlty Towers.

There was an attempt to translate the series to the US in a version starring Diana Rigg.  This series followed in the steps of several other British series with less than likeable main characters coming to the US with great success (Sanford & Son, All in the Family).  The series lasted through several episodes which were straight re-writes of the original.  The move from male to female lead did not work, and the emphasis on class differences necessary to the British version did not play in the States.

I am not going to list the episodes or heap masses of praise - others have done that.  I am going to tell you about my favorite episode - the Anniversary Party - where the normally obnoxious Basil tries to plan a surprise party for his wife, gets her so mad at him by pretending to have forgotten the event that she leaves, forcing him to resort to a small lie to placate the arriving guests.  This lie balloons with each arrival, until Basil is forced to hire Polly, the maid, to impersonate his wife.  In this episode you actually wind up feeling sorry for Basil, who, though hoist by his own petard, is doing what he thinks is best for good reasons with very bad results.

The episodes in this series are so tightly written that several of them actually seem like two separate episodes in terms of action (the concussion/fire alarm is a prime example).

This series is the best ever made.  It can be watched again and again and again.  If you have not discovered the joys of Fawlty Towers and its dysfunctional staff, rush out an rent or buy.

John Cleese is brilliant in this series, all the episodes are very well done.  I bought this for my mother at Christmas, and we watch it all the time.  The lines are geniusly laid out and it really is a great, worthwhile series to own.

This collection contains all 12 Fawlty Towers episodes.  The second season aired a few years after the first season.  It also contains additional footage/interviews.  Great collection especially if you love Monty Python!

I still don't understand why they made so few episodes.

For anyone who loves Monty Python or British comedy in general, Fawlty Towers is absolutely worthwhile. John Cleese is hilarious as always, this time playing an over-stressed, henpecked hotel manager. The supporting cast is wonderful as well. I would highly reccomend this collection.

Can't go wrong with this one... whether you're starting out with British comedy or know Fawlty Towers as a classic, it's a must-have addition to the DVD shelf. My boyfriend and I pull it out every now and then for a good evening laugh. Can watch it over and over again. Love it!

Basil Fawlty is truly a ghastly character.  Sybil and he are meant for each other.  Yet, they are so much fun to watch.  The cast of these classic sitcoms are so much fun--especially Manuel.  The slapstick involving Manuel is "roll on the floor" funny!  I keep asking myself why they made so few episodes, and it is really difficult to choose a favorite.  They are all hysterically funny.  However, please take note--don't ever stay in a hotel like Fawlty Towers!  Ha!

I grew up watching old episodes of Fawlty Towers on PBS with my dad.

I got this as a gift a few years ago and have watched them over and over again.  We continually quote lines from this show as we're doing things together even to this day.

I decided to replace my dad's VHS tapes this year (2007) for Christmas. He has had them for about 15 years or so, so they are pretty worn out.  He was really happy to get this.  Now we can revive some of our daily quotes to each other as we talk on the phone or when I visit their house.

It's too bad that BBC only made 12 episodes.  This could've been as great and well known as Monty Python had it continued for a few more years.

The DVDs are great quality.  There are a lot of interviews with the cast and behind the scenes looks at how this show came about.  I actually couldn't find it in stock in any stores in my area (Portland, Oregon)...no one bothers to carry this great show anymore!!!  Not Best Buy, Target, Fred Meyer, Borders, or Suncoast Movie Company.  Thank you Amazon!

"This Basil's wife.  This Basil.  This smack on head."

The first order for Fawlty Towers was due to be received on December 19.  It did not arrive.  I contacted Amazon.  A second order was sent and was received on December 24 (in time for Christmas).  I received the first order on January 3 and contacted Danielle at Amazon.  She e-mailed a new address label and the package was mailed back to Amazon on January 4.  Danielle was very helpful.  Thank you.
This set is perfect for the British comedy enthusiast.  The complete series (everyone has a favorite episode!), great DVD quality, much better than the old VCR tapes!

Who couldn't love this British humor? There are times in the series that you feel bad for Mr. Fawlty but you can't help but laugh, (quilt ridden no less.)This series is about a man and his wife who own an Inn in Torkay. You begin to feel sorry for the old chap but just as you do he does something so bizarre you're on the edge of your seat waiting to see how he'll get out of the latest jam, and how he'll keep it from his wife, no less. In the end it is hard to feel for him because he's always cooking up some big idea that turns into one giant mess!! Fawlty Towers - The Complete SeriesI've watch these episodes over and over for years you couldn't make a better investment in laughter!!

In my opinion, this is the Best SitCom ever, and I have seen my share of them. John Cleese is, in my opinion, the funniest man alive on TV.

Here are some other examples:

- Fierce Creatures

- Monty Python and the Life of Brian
