Full 12 episodes of Fawlty Towers...if you are a fan of the show you will love this dvd...classic.
takes me back to when i was a child. John Cleese is so funny in this show

I have had this DVD collection for a couple of years.  I bought it for a friend who had recently developed a 'taste' for British humor.  I told him this will be a feast.  He was not disappointed.

I don't think there could've been any TV series more satisfying that Fawlty Towers.  After rewatching these episodes over and over, I still marvel at their story structure and the brilliant comedic situations they managed to come up with.  My personal favorites are 'Communications Problems' and 'The Psychiatrist'.  In addition to the brilliance of John Cleese, the casting of the supportive players was pure genius.

These episodes are now over 30 years old, but they still beat anything on TV today.  That's a pretty strong testament to the writing of this classic series.

Recently watched four episodes after not seeing the series for at least 10 years. Caught lots more than I did in the past, probably due to increased life experience pointing up the principles involved in most work environments. Unless one is put off/confused by the series's Britishisms, this will function as classic comedy descended from the likes of The Honeymooners, Laurel & Hardy, & even Wodehouse. It's some of the funniest stuff I've ever seen, with something for everyone but anyone who might be offended by the treatment of the Manuel character, but hilarity tends to override such concerns. Potential demonstrated by Cleese in Monty Python comes to delightfully manic fruition. Cleese is often given a run for his money by Prunella Scales's deliciously pretentious, instantly recognizable character, embodying everything comforting, annoying, and amusing in what might in America be called the "upper working class."  I think the seriously ill should watch this in concert with any prescribed medications - if nothing else, they'll go out laughing.

The set is expensive but well worth it. I bought it at a retail outlet & paid much more than what is listed here. This is the best British TV series I have ever seen. My exposure to British series is limited though, I've only seen what has been aired on PBS. Of all those that I'm familiar with, this one is the least British. John Cleese & company are a riot; some of this borders on slapstick. Hilarious is the best word that comes to mind.
The quality of the discs are excellent & includes a lot of bonus materials. Though expensive, this set was well worth the price. Enjoy one of the funniest shows that's ever been produced anywhere in the world!!!

Very little of what has ever been on TV can accurately be called essential viewing, but this brief but magnificent series is surely one of them. For those who have never witnessed an episode of "Fawlty Towers," you will want to forget most of what you thought you knew about John Cleese from his immortal Python days. Certainly all of the physical comedy is intact, as well as Cleese's love of humor derived from the fertile fields of embarrassment and miscommunication. But in "Fawlty Towers" all of Cleese's best instincts as both a comedian and a humorist are refined by orders of magnitude, and more prominently on display than they ever could have been in the crowded Python collaboration.

This is screamingly funny stuff. But even more importantly, the material resonates deeply on a human level. Basil Fawlty may be the rudest, most obnoxious, impatient, pigheaded and vein individual ever portrayed on the tiny screen -- but if we don't see just a little bit of our own vanities and foibles in Basil, then we're probably not being entirely honest with ourselves. Much of the astonishing intensity of the humor in "Fawlty Towers" springs from the little voice inside our heads that says, "There but for the grace of God go I."

To Cleese's great credit, he hold Basil up more for examination than ridicule. Although clearly Basil is his own worst enemy, and while we could not possible feel any real warmth toward him, we nevertheless sympathize with his plight. This sharpness of observation is why "Fawlty Towers" is more than just a funny TV series, and why it soars to very special and rare heights. Simply said, this series is a work of genuine comic genius.

As far as the DVD set is concerned, American viewers have to be continually disappointed with the decision of BBC Warner to release British TV shows on DVD in the US 4:3 (1.33:1) format instead of their original PAL screen ratio. In that sense, American viewers have never actually seen the complete "Fawlty Towers." What a shame, and how completely unnecessary. This set comes with special feature cast members interviews which were produced in a surprisingly amateurish manner. They're better than nothing, but such an important TV series certainly deserved a higher quality treatment.

I saw a few of these episodes about 10-15 years ago on my local public television station, and was reminded of them by my husband, who really wanted to get the complete set.  We have not been sorry.  Every episode is a gem.  John Cleese at his best.

I absolutely love it!!  If you are at all a John Cleese fan or a Monty Python fan you will love "Fawlty Towers".  It is a shame they only made 12 episodes, but they are amazing.  I have seen them each about five times and I still laugh!

John Cleese is priceless as want-to-be highbrow hotelier Basil Fawlty in this madcap series about life at the fictional Fawlty Towers Hotel in Torquay, England.  Enthusiasts of slapstick comedy will marvel at the contortions Cleese and the marvelous Andrew Sachs (Manuel) put themselves through, and Prunella Scales does a wonderful job portraying the put-upon -- and occasionally trying in her own right -- Sybil Fawlty.  Inspired writing by Cleese and then-wife Connie Booth (the show's capable housekeeper) makes these programs a joy to experience as Basil's aspirations toward an upper class clientele result in ever-greater disasters.

Great to have all these hilarious episodes in one DVD set.  Cool  interviews with  John Cleese, Prunella Scales and Andrew Sachs.  Re-live all your favourite lines from Basil and Sybil...but whatever you do, don't mention the war, order the duck or forget to say happy anniversary!

All episodes are hilariously funny. Over the past 20 years I watched the home-recorded VHS Tapes of the aired progams over and over again. However, with this set of DVDs, the far superior image and sound quality make watching it much more enjoyable.
If you enjoy classic British humour this is the DVD for you.  It's fast past and you're never sure of what is coming next.
I purchased this product for my mom who is a great fan of British comedy.  We both love this series.
Cleese is great as the inept Fawlty.  The supporting characters are wonderful in every episode.  Fawlty is the perfect victim.

The only thing I can add to the already lengthy reviews on this set is a warning.  It was written a long time ago, and there is dialog that might offend tender ears, and the sensibilities of modern race relations.

A few very mild swear words are sprinkled about, not terrible ones, but not for the easily offended or young.

The warning I would add is that the old Major is very, very politically incorrect, and was even for his time.  I think the writers meant for us to be jolted by his language, and weren't condoning his racisim.  I'd watched this series over and over on PBS where the offending remarks had been deleted out, and never missed.

Kevin Murphy of Mystery Science Theater 3000 (another show all comedy fans should own on DVD) said it best once when he referred to Fawlty Towers as the "greatest sitcom" ever. I simply cannot say enough good things about the show. Even after repeated viewings over many years it is amazingly funny; no surprise there, Cleese and Booth crafted each script for six weeks till the comedy was honed to a razor edge. By limiting themselves to just six shows per series and spacing the two series a few years apart, they were able to spend enough time on each script to ensure that there were no wasted lines or filler, it's pure comedy from start to finish. Nearly every moment of the show is used as an opportunity to generate laughter.

The extras on this DVD set are also worth viewing. They include a concise, informative interview with John Cleese, a brief bit about the fate of the building used as Fawlty Towers in the show, a documentary on the Gleneagles Hotel in England which inspired the show, and more.

My only complaint about this DVD set and the only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is the picture quality. The picture quality is simply inexcusable for DVD. It is grainy and fuzzy in many spots and there are even some color anomalies that pop up occasionally. A show of this caliber certainly deserves better, especially on a medium that can provide terrific picture quality. My old VHS copy of the show had a better picture quality. The DVD at times looks degraded in a way similar to a VHS tape that has been watched hundreds of times.

Picture quality notwithstanding, any comedy fan, especially those who appreciate off-beat comedy like Monty Python's Flying Circus, Black Adder, Mystery Science Theater 3000, Red Dwarf, etc. will LOVE Fawlty Towers. In spite of the picture quality, you will enjoy this immensely.

John Cleese and team never fail to leave you laughing.  If you like british humor, you will love this set.  Lots of credit to the other actors and actresses, I don't know how they keep up with Cleese (I would be surprised if it was all in the script) and not break in to laughter themselves.  Along the same lines, you may want to check out a Fish Called Wanda

Anyone who claims to love British comedy has to watch this, if for no other reason than to have the basis for appreciating more modern fare like The Office or Clatterford.  If you are put off by the geekfest that is the Monty Python fan club, fear not - this bears no likeness, and there are precious few catchphrases to repeat ad nauseum. This is a classic, but it is by no means highbrow or even a little bit intellectual - it is replete with sight gags, slapstick and rats in the restaurant.  It may not sound like it, but this series is necessary viewing for the BBC set.

There is indeed nothing faulty with Fawlty Towers.
This Britcom which was first filmed in 1975 then added to later in 1979 is an enduring classic of its genre and is definitely one of the all time best....period.
It's star John Cleese along with then-wife and co-star(Polly)Connie Booth collaborated on the entire series together. Most of the series was filmed in studio but there were quite a few exterior shots and they used the Wooburn Grange Country Club in Torquay,England for that purpose. The club itself has since burned down and been bulldozed to make way for residential development.
However Cleeses' actual inspiration for the character of Basil Fawlty comes from one Mr. Sinclair(now deceased) the o/o of the GlenEagles Hotel in Torquay. It seems Cleese and some of the Monty Python cast and crew were staying at the GlenEagles and experienced some of Mr. Sinclair's,shall we say,"inestimable charm" first hand. Most of the group was not amused and off most trotted to a nearby and more forgiving establishment for the duration of their stay there. Cleese however was intrigued by the utter gall,bluster and plain rudeness of Mr. Sinclair and thought he would stay to observe this local phenom up close and personal. From that experience sprang forth the idea for Basil Fawlty and the rest is sitcom history.
Fawlty Towers has created a minor tourism point of call for the GlenEagles Hotel in Torquay and the surrounding area .Buses and folks from all over the world come there to have a glimpse of the famous hotel which inspried this wonderful show. Depending on who one talks to the oppinions of locals range from happy to embarassed but very rarely negative. And this is quite a testament to just a 12 episode Britcom which during its' first airing in 1975 didn't get much attention at all. It wasn't until its' re-runs the following years that the groundswell gathered steam which eventually prompted more eps to be filmed in 1979. When you look at them today it is almost nigh impossible to tell where the /75-ers start and the /79-ers end. Again another indication of the over all quality of the show from top to bottom.
Technically speaking this show has been transferred very well from tape. The contrast and colours have been cleaned up and it looks better than it ever did.
The three discs included with this set(not four as indicated above by one of the product reviewers)comes with interviews with Cleese,Sachs(Manuel) and Scales(Mrs. Fawlty),trips to Torquay,out takes,directors commentaries and more.
The reason I'm not giving this higher stars is because of the lack of any inserts with episode information. There is an extremely lean blurb for each ep on the back cover of the set but that's it. One assumes also that the eps listed are in order but it would have been nice to have at least release dates but sadly there are none. I think for the price BBC video could have plumped this set up a bit.
In conclusion except for the minor drawbacks listed this set generally is worth getting for any fan of good comedy sitcoms and /or Britcoms. It's humour and characters are universally indentifiable and work on many levels. It is still fast paced(in large part due to its' judicious editing) and plain laugh out loud funny. A real "inn-keeper"!!
I love this show!! you gotta see it!
I bought this DVD on request from my 10 yr old son who also loved the Monty Python set. Now Fawlty towers is his favourite and all 12 episodes too! Thanks so much for making this available!
Bought this DVD for my husband and he loved it! The complete series, how much better can you get?
It's John Cleese and this was just totally worth purchasing!
this is a classic british sitcom that has the slighty on the edge of sanitity basil fawlty running around like a headless chicken it is a must see so buy it now!

ABSOLUTELY HILARIOUS!!

Just as funny watching it for the 50th time.

Classic British Humour!
If you are a British sitcom fan, and a John Cleese fan - this set is heaven! I laugh so hard my sides hurt!Fawlty Towers - The Complete Series

It's a real shame this series wasn't afforded a decent run because, had it been, I really believe Fawlty Towers would have become one of the greatest British comedy shows ever, right up there with John Cleese's old show at Monty Python.

My favorite episode is "The Builders."  The one part that leave my sides hurting from laughing so hard is the one where Sybil Fawlty comes back to find that O'Reilly's workmen have screwed up yet again (this after already hiring a competent, yet expensive, contractor to do the work).  Mr. O'Reilly claims that he, "...likes a woman with spirit," to which Sybil responds with, "Oh, do you?  Is that what you like?"  Mr. O'Reilly assures her, enthusiastically responding, "I do! I do!" Sybil: "Oh good."  She then proceeds to whack her husband in the stomach with an umbrella and then starts beating the living daylights out of O'Reilly while she says, "Come on, then, give us a smile."  With O'Reilly crouched against the check-in desk Sybil proclaims: "I've seen better creatures than you lying on their backs at the bottom of ponds."

Fawlty Towers is British comedy, and comedy in general, at its best.  John Cleese's comedic timing and delivery are on-target (as always), and I'm really sorry to see there are only so many episodes to this fantastic comedy.  - Donna Di Giacomo

Fawlty Towers is one of the funniest shows of all time.  It's a little expensive for twelve episiodes but I bought it new when it was on sale.  Plus, you can watch these episodes again and again and because of the quick humor you'll laugh every time.  Definitely add Fawlty Towers to your collection!
It's the funniest series ever produced for television.  Already had it on VHS...now have it on DVD.

As a teenager back in the late 80s early 90s, my parents had at some time bought some vhs tapes of some of the Faulty Towers series. We used to watch them over and over again. Finally, I noticed they had come out with a complete season series on dvd. My wife and I purchased it as soon as we found out they were available on dvd. As my wife had never watched, let alone heard of this show, weve had many hours of intense laughter on the couch together watching Basil and crew mess up everything over and over again.

The Fawlty Towers episodes are hilarious and deserve their growing cult status.  However, this DVD set is poor quality and not recommended.  The problem is the compression used in order to fit the series on three DVDs:  the frame-rate has been significantly reduced.  This would be mostly unnoticeable on a slow moving film, but there is considerable amounts of fast movement in Fawlty Towers, so the result is a very distracting, jerky effect where actors magically jump from one position to the next.  There is also a graining quality to the image that suggests other types of compression.  What's the point of a DVD when the VHS delivers better viewing?
if you are a fan -- classic and timeless, and if you have never seen this -- you can't help but laugh at John Cleese and the rest of the Fawlty staff

John Cleese as the lovably rude and intolerant Basil Fawlty is at the top of his craft. He excels beyond even his best sketches of Monty Python fame.  I have seen every Fawlty Towers episode at least 10 times and each time I find myself laughing until I can't see through the tears.  And I continue to go back to them time and time again.  Check out the episodes "Communications Problems" and "The Corpse and the Kippers" for some of the most brilliant comedic acting and writing that you are likely to ever come across.

John Cleese portrays the cheap and incompetent hotel owner Basil Fawlty, Andrew Sachs is the perpetually hounded and bumbling waiter Manuel ("He's from Barcelona"), Prunella Scales plays Basil's bossy wife Sybil (Basil's  "little nest of vipers") , and Connie Booth plays the most competent character of the bunch but who is forever getting swept up into Basil's tangled schemes. The cast is outstanding and the writing is pure genius.

It is said that laughter is the best medicine, and a dose of Fawlty Towers will have you feeling better faster than you can say, "It would be easier to train a monkey."

This is a fantastic series that earns the accolades in the other reviews.  John Cleese's situation comedy only ran for two seasons for a total of 12 episodes, but it is clear that the Monty Python alumnus crafted these shows with a special care.

The result is a series that gets funnier as it progresses.  Cleese is "Basil Fawlty" our (anti-)hero, the misanthropic owner/manager of the hotel referred to in the title.  The episodes demonstrate his frentic attempts at either trying to increase the social standing of his establishment, or alternatively, just keep it running.  In these attempts, he confronts many formidable and/or obnoxious characters (the best of which would come down to either his own wife or the hard-of-hearing Mrs. Richards).  Too cowardly to confront these characters, Basil channels his frustrations to the innocent or harmless...usually his own incompetent bellboy.

What really distinguishes this series is the timing and editing.  There are websites devoted to the structure of these programs and how the plot develops.  Watching any episode, you can feel the tension building as Basil's latest crisis escalates beyond his abilities.  By the tme you get to the final minutes, you are laughing as a release as much as a reaction to the antics.

It's not perfect--some characters never really click (the Major), and its not a very polished production (some lines are inaudible).  All in all though this is one of the few television series worth owning.  An average rating of five-stars over two hundred reviews on Amazon should be a good indication of that.

Great stuff. The only thing wrong with this set is that's all there is. They only made a few episodes ever, which makes this set priceless. The extra footage on the DVDs was quite good and gave some history of the show.

As a fan of Little Britain, Goodness Gracious Me, The Kumars at no. 42, Mr. Bean, My Family, The League of Gentlemen etc etc, I've been hooked on British comedy. We recently received a new British channel here in Malaysia on cable tv (BBC Entertainment) and one of the very first comedies I've watched is Fawlty Towers. I recognized Cleese from Rat's Race but at first I thought the series is old, crappy and Basil's character is quite annoying (and so is Sybil) but the more I watched it, the more addicted I get and soon I'm hooked! I love British humor. Every episodes is fresh and funny. I also love the little 'goof' they have (The sign "FAWLTY TOWERS" keeps changing at the beginning).

The DVD is way too expensive for me but if you love British humor, I fully recommend Fawlty Towers and you won't regret it!

If you like Mr. Bean, Blackadder, The Thin Blue Line or Are you Being Served, you will probably enjoy Fawlty Towers. I had never heard of it until Amazon recommended it for me based on my love of 'The Thin Blue Line'.

Anyway, John Cleese plays Basil a very hen pecked, overworked and kind of antisocial but good guy. His wife is always talking on the phone and talking the guests ears off.  The supporting cast is excellent as well. My favorite episode is 'The Germans'. I watch these 12 episodes over and over. So very hilarious!
if you need your spirits lifted and brit humour is your bag this one will do it.
Although dated sets detract somewhat the overall effect is splendid.  A must have in any collection.

It was a delight, the price was right, the DVD was top quality and it arrived a few days after the purchase order went in. I watch the sit-coms every other day. Its always fresh.

I would recommend this DVD set to all who like comedy.

I purchased Fawlty Towers for a French friend of mine. I couldn't bare the thought of him not being acquainted with this masterpiece of British hilarious craziness. He loves it. If he hadn't, our friendship would have been seriously jeopardized.
MAKE NO MISTAKE. THIS IS THE BEST DVD SET YOU WILL EVER BUY. AT LESS THAN THIRTY BUCKS, FU GET A BOUT IT!
I got these for my parents, we watched them together when I was a child.  It was a great thrill to have them again.

Fawlty Towers is a rip roaring good laughfest. The neurotic and ever anguished Basil Fawlty brings new meaning to tortured soul. Fawlty Towers is the perfect way to enjoy an easy Sunday. Don't forget your tea and crumpets!

Although there were only 12 episodes released in the 70's, this is classic British humor that will continue entertaining us forever. John Cleese (Monty Python)is at his very best. John plays 'Basil Fawlty' a witty schemeing obnoxious hotel manager usually out for personal gain, is surrounded by a cast of many unique personalities that always ends up in total chaos. Good clean entertainment.

I recently bought this DVD to replace two worn out VHS

tapes of Fawlty Towers that I taped off public television

19 years ago.  John Cleese and his then wife, American

Connie Booth, co-wrote the series together back in the mid-

seventies, it's about a rude hotel owner and his interactions

with his guests and staff.  They spent a week writing each episode.  They sat side by side at a large table with a big roll of butcher paper

in front of them and they would write down story lines, plots,

funny words and sentences that would come to them.  Then they

would bring these ideas together - pretty amazing.  The humor

is fast paced with many plots and subplots merging brilliantly

in the end.  My favorites episodes are: "The Germans", "Basil

and the Rat" and the "Psychiatrist".  This is a great DVD!
Very funny!  John Cleese is hilarious as is the entire cast.  Its only a shame they didn't make more episodes.  I highly recommended this for Monty Python lovers and anyone who loves to laugh.

Possibly, with Black Adder, the best and funniest series ever done. The John Cleese

of Monty Python is the superbly arrogant and incompetent  Basil; Manuel (he's from

Barcelona) will bleat "I know nawthing..." and Sybil, on the phone, will endlessly

repeat "I knaow...I knaow..." to her equally irascible friends.

Classic, disarmingly funny, quotable and a joy forever. Buy the package. Infrequent

appearances on PBS are nowhere near enough.
The product and seller were both 1st rate.  Received item in great condition very quickly.

You don't know whether to laugh or look on in disbelief.  A great comedy that will keep you in stitches.

A good way to unwind after a long and hard day!
If you like British humor at all, this is a must buy. Even if you are not a big fan of the Brit's dry wit, The interaction between Basil and his wife is worth the purchase. Enjoy!

Finally, after long searching, I've found the complete set of Fawlty Towers. The visual quality is good (certainly better than my home-recorded video tapes!) but no 'cleaning' has been done to the image... Nothing matches the pent-up anger of Basil Fawlty cursing the Heavens, or beating his mini with a tree branch. The smarmy, unctuous sycophant has since never been so well portrayed. A real laugh-a-minute series, with tight dialogue and unforgettable characters. Do not pass this collection by!

I absolutely love BBC programming, and Fawlty Towers is probably the best written---both clever and just plain goofy. There is also a nice mini-documentary about how the series came about. At the price, this is a fantastic entertainment value.
Great and funny show!! Sure wish they had done more than the 16 episodes.
this is funny stuff. it's a must have for any monty python lover.

If Santa Claus is coming to town, Basil Fawlty is on his best behavior. If not, he's like you or me. Or is he?

Fawlty Towers is a comedy series about man and wife who run a self-named hotel. The hotel seems nice enough, though in need of a few repairs. They have a staff of two- a man from Barcelona who speaks very little English and a young blond woman whose beauty is what is attracts the most attention. John Cleese as Basil Fawlty is the main character and it's his sarcastic humor, his immense groveling and his pie-in-the-face antics that define the comedy of this series. It's British, it's backwards, and it has made me laugh because it's so basic.

But then again, it's not all clean humor. There are sexual references and innuendo that make me squirm watching it with my young ones (the wedding party). It does, also, cross the line into peeking and groping, though for seemingly innocent reasons (the psychiatrist). Our kids are not allowed to watch an episode that we haven't screened. After watching this first episode listed above, we waited 6 weeks (after the Christmas season) to screen anymore. Last night, we screened two, one of them being the latter listed above.

I find the sexual humor offensive. As a teen, I laughed while watching, but had nightmares afterwards. That was in the days before taping where shows weren't pre-screened and offensive material couldn't be skipped through the magic of fast forward or scene selection.

My recommendation is to watch with a friend who knows which episodes to avoid, if you can find such a friend. And then screen, screen, screen before allowing the kids to watch. Some of it will be over their heads, but watch out, because some memories will stick with them long after Fawlty Towers has been closed for repairs.

Too bad John Cleese and Connie Booth only wrote & produced 12 episodes, but re-playing them every once in a while will still provide enough laughs to cheer anyone up.

Anyone, that is, who likes to see the old-fashioned Britisher's penchant for public politeness and starchy protocol (no-matter-what the situation) get muddled and overcome by the practicalities of everyday life and the evolving (at the time) impatience with the stiff-upper-lip facade of British society -- a facade that began crumbling with the advent of Monty Python.  If you like watching how the Brits learned to poke fun at themselves in publicly-aired media, this one's for you.

Most episodes have that Monty Pythonian touch where over-exaggeration of a situation provides quite a bit of the humor, but the dialogs in Fawlty Towers are generally more witty and less slapstick than most of the Monty Python movies or TV skits I've seen.  An exception was the "Waldorf Salad" episode where the situation was exaggerated to an extreme that was too implausible to be funny, but even that episode has numerous punch lines that will evoke hearty laughter when regurgitated to those familiar with this outstanding series of 12.
This is a set of all 12 episodes and is a very good deal. A must for all Fawlty Towers fans! All the characters are excellent, the way a real comedy should be.
Everytime I view episodes in this series, they seem to get funnier.  This series is definitely a keeper.
I enjoyed my purchase and it arrived in perfect condition and was quickly received.

What can I add that my title has not already said, in my opinion this is the finest Situation Comedy ever made anywhere, U.K., U.S. or anywhere else., A True Classic and the DVD boxed set was very well done with lots if great extras.
Humor the whole family can enjoy and will understand. Nothing to offend, although not entirely PC by todays standards, still hilarious.

The reason I purchased this DVD is John Cleese, as he is the best comedian

for slapstick and keeps me in stiches laughing. Anyway a good few hours spent with good clean comedy.
I purchased this as a gift for someone who enjoys British comedy.  He says it was "right on."

Naturally, a personal view ... but as mentioned it  has always been a favorite of mine.  Very well written.  Funny to the extreme.  I love it.  Full of very subtle comedy, and Basil's "razor-sharp wit".  Not the best for American's who have a problem understanding British humour.  Personally, but I am British, I would not be without this in my collection.
John Cleese at his best.  I thoroughly enjoyed watching this series and it definately left me wanting more.

Anyone looking at this DVD set of all 12 episodes most likely knows the series, and has seen part or all of it somewhere else.  If not, what rock have you been under?  I saw this series first on American PBS in 1982 and was struck by the brilliant writing, physical acting and clever dynamic of the cast.  At the time America only turned out sitcoms filled with dull jokes, tepid characters, heavily inflated laugh tracks, or the Fonz striking poses as the crowd wailed mercilessly in rapture.  Stale.  Amazingly, classmates of mine in high school at the time claimed it was boring and couldn't understand the plots.  And they were never heard of again.

This 70's BBC series is classic, and a must have for any comedy lover.  Dated, but it has its place.  Much of the writing and comedic action is still leaps ahead of modern fare, despite being one of the cheapest series produced at the time by the BBC (in 1974).

Shows are uncut and unadulterated.  No special correction or computer fixes to small imperfections.  Thank god.  It is a very classy and straight forward package.  Mr. Davies and Mr. Spiers provide commentary tracks which are nearly to sleep by.  Davies is mostly quiet, and his gurgling stomach is constantly providing commentary while Spiers is heard endlessly drinking, smoking or exercising Restless Leg Syndrome.  And it sounds like it was shot in someone's spare bedroom.  Still good for a one time listen by fans of the series, but not worth it if you just like the shows and don't care about where cameras were position, or how long make up took.
This is a first rate product at a very fair price.  I enjoyed watching it over and over again.  John Cleese is brilliant!

Sent this to Europe and package arrived pretty quickly.  These shows were a favorite some years ago and I was thrilled to find them available through Amazon.  Simple process that went smoothly.  Thanks.

John Cleese is absolutely brilliant as Basil Fawlty.  There have been attempts at recapturing the humor Fawlty Towers produced, but they all grey in comparison.  This is a must see for any John Cleese fan, or for anyone with a slightly warped sense of humor.

Just fantastic , brings rich comedy back with the same impact you saw this first time on TV.

Ideal for repeat viewings any time of the day to cheer you up
If you like John Cleese, this is for you.  Worth every cent of the purchase price.
Excellent!! Classic!  Very Funny especially Basil the Rat!  Won't be disappointed!

Seriously, folks, IMO this is THE funniest TV series of all time.  Brilliant scripting and acting.  Plot twists that combine hilarity with a tinge of Shakespearean tragedy (Mr. Fawlty's character flaws often lead him into the very trouble he is so desperately trying to avoid).  John Cleese is a comic genius, there is no other word for it.  This is a series that is most definitely worth owning and cherishing and re-watching every now and then.

In my opinion, it's a toss-up between this and Blackadder as the greatest British comedy of all time. Warning: this complete set includes rather lengthy (and not always interesting) interviews with John Cleese before every episode. If you have no interest in the script-writing process or Cleese's relationship with the actor who played Manuel, then that might be a minor bother you'll have to fast forward through. But even so- this is a great series.

This is some of John Cleese's best work! Cleese plays Basil Fawlty: a singularly inhospitable manager of a small hotel. He takes bad customer service to the ridiculous extreme. It is uproariously funny to watch the terrible mess he causes for himself. The good writing, well designed cast of characters, snappy timing, and witty dialogue had me hooked from the first episode. I would highly recommend this to anyone who likes Monty Python's Flying Circus, British humour, or just laughing in general!

fawlty towers is one of the most hillarious shows ever!!!! i could watch basil fawlty forever and still be entertained!!!

recomended to all who are normal and those who are not.
The funniest sit com ever. You can watch it several times and still laugh out loud.

I have loved Faulty Towers for years.  I wasn't aware there were just 12 episodes.  But I am so glad to have them, Now my 17 year old daughter and 12 year old nephew love them too.  The Amazon price was awesome too.  I saw this at a very large and well known bookstore for 49.95.  Try this product if you really like comedy, you will not be disappointed.

If I were to say to you 'i've discovered this farce set in a British hotel with wobbly sets , featuring a spanish waiter who says que ? all the time ..and a mad major , you might well say,  'You know I think I'll give it a miss..' Well you'd be making a very grave error because even 30 years after it was first aired, Fawlty Towers is still incredibly funny. It shouldn't be ....but it is. This is in no small part to John Cleese and Prunella Scales, the nightmare husband and wife team around which much of the farce resolves . The tragedy that is their marriage is the bedrock of much of the humor. Also the whole concept of a hotel run by a manager (Cleese ) who is amazingly rude to his guests, unless they are of the right class, is comic gold.
Even after all of these years, Fawlty Towers still makes me laugh until I cry.  It is hysterical!  A must buy!

It almost brings tears to my eyes to see an American audience so in love with, what is, after all, a quintessentially English sitcom. My views have changed somewhat regarding the American sense of humour, it has always seemed to me that we English can appreciate "good" (Frasier, Cheers, Friends) American comedy but the reverse didn't appear to be true, not in the case of Fawlty Towers it seems!! This really, is a review of the reviews by the American people who have watched and loved this programme. As I said earlier, this is "very" English humour, the irony, sarcasm etc. that up until now I believed Americans didn't "get". Thankyou everyone who reviewed Fawlty Towers with very apt descriptions of the action, it's obvious that you do understand at least some of our humour. Hopefully this will give you a different idea of what our humour is about and maybe you will seek out other (as you call it) Britcoms, such as "Only Fools And Horses", as, having appreciated Fawlty Towers, you won't fail to be charmed by The Trotters!!! Happy veiwing.

"Fawlty Towers" is still the funniest sitcom I've ever seen, and anyone who loves comedy and hasn't seen it, should. The additional features on the DVD were also interesting, especially the background on the location. A+++!

Not normally a fan of physical comedy, with the exception of Benny Hill, Fawlty Towers has got to be one of the funniest British comedies ever broadcast on television.

With over 237 reviews of this 4 disc DVD set here on Amazon.com, I don't think I need to expand on the merits of each episode; nonetheless, Basil Fawlty (John Cleese) is such a pathetic but amusing character you cannot help laughing at. Supporting cast including Prunella Scales and Connie Booth (who co-wrote the series) are, of course, are the perfect comedic foil to our beleaguered and boorish host. Other supporting characters are also superb.

Overall, this is a very nicely done set with additional footage and interviews from some of the cast as well as a short documentary on the actual hotel (unfortunately destroyed in a fire) in Torquay, England, where the series was filmed outside of the studio.

While "Monty Python's Flying Circus" may be a little off-the-wall or hard to take for some audiences, "Fawlty Towers" is the perfect antidote to the typical American situation comedy.

Although not of a sophisticated or urbane wit or satire as say, "Yes, Minister," with Nigel Hawthorne and Paul Eddington, "Fawlty Towers" does offer the viewer a lens into the comedic slapstick genius of John Cleese and some truly exceptional writing for a 30 minute program.
If you are a big fan of british comedy especially Monty Python you'll love this collection of Fawlty Towers episodes starring John Cleese.

Ordinarily do not like slapstick, however, Cleese is a genius and Cleese and Booth provided excellent scripts. Would have given it 5 Stars if there were more extras. Not enough outtakes and no interviews with Booth or Sachs.

Fawlty Towers has to rank as one of the very finest, and funny, British Sitcoms ever produced.  The writing and acting are without peer and unfortunately not found in the great majority of what passes as TV comedy shows today. The material is not dated and depends upon sight gags more often than not.  You will find it very hard not to have a marathon session with Fawlty and his gang of hotel help....enjoy ! Ed Sponable, Falls Church, VA
This has to be the funniest and most entertaining collections I have ever watched. We had seen it on PBS a couple times and it never grows old.  Just great humor!
The show is hilarious and the DVD quality is just fine. If you remember this show, this set is perfect for you!

Spanning just 12 episodes (by design), Fawlty Towers is one of the great gems of British comedy, with the tall and lanky John Cleese as Basil Fawlty, owner of a small hotel which would run smoothly if not for his habit of getting into the most hilarious situations due to his boorish and obnoxious behaviour.

The supporting characters, like Manuel (Andrew Sachs) who barely speaks English, Basil's wife Sybil (Prunella Scales) and Polly  the maid (Connie Booth, who shares screenwriting credit with Cleese) are all perfect as their respective characters, serving more as a counterpoint to Cleese's madness. Highly recommended.

Mr. Fawlty is the hotel manager in over his head, while trying his best to manage the chaos which swirls around him.  His stoic, quietly no-nonsense wife is the rock, supported by her young blond assistant, and the waiter, a young latin man learning English.  What happens in the hotel as the hotel guests interact with Mr. Fawlty, his wife and staff is delightful fun.  I recommend Fawlty Towers - The Complete Collection.

I have watched this several times and I still laugh out loud every time. "Fawlty Towers" is one of the best British comedy shows ever made. My only complain is that only a handful of episodes were ever made.

I don't buy TV shows on DVD and I never recommend anybody to do so; but this is the exception to the rule.

that the dedicated fans of this show presume everybody who sees the show loves it. That is far from the case. Many people can watch Python or FT and easily nopt enjoy it. I for one see little humor in this series. Remember FT/python fans you don't speak for everyone when you write how you admire these tv works.

As many others have noted, Fawlty Towers is a truly hilarious series. The only show I can think of that's funnier (to me) is "Arrested Development" and it took 25 years for any comedy series to surpass FT.  Every episode is a gem, but my favorite is "Gourmet Night." The scene where Basil goes berserk and starts thrashing his car with a tree branch is just one of the funniest TV moments EVER!  I bought the series on VHS tape years ago, and I'd upgrade to the DVD set if were more reasonably priced.  Three bucks an episode is a bit steep for 30-year-old TV episodes; most US series go for about half that.  Still, FT is a classic, and there are some decent extras on this set.  If I didn't already own it on tape I'd probably spring for it.

John Cleese And Connie Booth have created one of the most hilarious comedies of all time.  The English sense of humor is something that I just can't get enough of; I watch an episode or two every week.  This is one of my best purchases so far.
I had ordered this thinking it would be months before it was delivered. To my surprise it was delivered quickly and the safely and it was exactly the thing I had ordered. Thank you.
This set is so funny you will split your sides laughing. I wish there were more episodes.

This collection of all 12 episodes of Fawlty Towers is great! It is a nicely packaged 3-disc set and the episodes are all classic and gut-bustingly hilarious. I highly recommend purchasing this complete set.
It is rich british humor at it's best.  Origianl writing and funny anagrams of fautly towers on the sign all great

Those 12 episodes of Fawlty Towers are absolutely hilarious. John Cleese and the whole team give a superbly funny performance, exploiting all aspects of comic (character, speech and situation comedy, mime...).

To be watched again and again, every time you need to cheer up or enjoy a GOOD laugh.

I find this to be the funniest TV comedy, ever. Seriously the laugh-out-loud, double over type of laughing that makes the people outside your dorm room think you're crazy. I highly recommend this collection, and I promise you'll watch it many times.

Here it is in all its glory, Fawlty Towers.  Now in DVD and better than ever.  The extra stuff (interviews and outtakes) is a delight.  Arguably the best sitcom ever; unarguably one of the funniest.  A great buy at any price.
The Fawlty Towers Collection proves that comedy does not have to be vulgar or suggestive.  It is good clean fun that really makes people laugh out loud.  I would recommend it to anyone.

This is NO JOKE- John Cleese's BEST stuff is in these episodes! He's an eccentric hotel owner who just doesnt like customers- it's hilarious! Its not just good all-round humor, but the physical aspects and just the antics of John are HILARIOUS!!!! He and his then wife Connie Booth wrote the series, and it's great!

The DVD's are worth it because the bonus features are good (not great) with some interesting interviews and it has subtitles for the episodes in case you can't quite understand the english. :)

Fawlty Towers by John Cleese and Connie Booth is one of the finest British television shows ever produced.  Following the venerable, yet annoying tradition of producing a very minimal set of episodes, this series manages to be one of the best comedies on television.  Ever.

Basil Fawlty (Cleese) stars as a hotel owner/operator with a bone to pick - with everyone he meets.  His wife, Sybil, (Prunella Scales) is equally hilarious for her total snobbish disdain for Basil.  In truth, the hotel stays afloat only by the hard work of the inept Manuel (Sachs) and the artist Polly (Booth) - but don't tell Basil that.  He is convinced that he is the pride of Fawlty Towers.

The series episodes contain a healthy dose of slapstick comedy to offset the ever-present dry British wit that underlies the entire program.

As an American viewer, I find the series fascinating, and my quickest 'boost' when I am having a bad day.

Hilarious, funny, and always entertaining, this DVD set is the perfect way to experience Fawlty Towers.

This was a gift for my husband who feels Fawlty Towers is one of the funiest British comedies going.  He was surprised that I had found it, and pleased beyond all my expectations with the quality of the DVD.

Fawlty Towers was a very dysfunctional hotel! On the sign outside the hotel, shown at the beginning of each episode, is the name of the hotel. Its name was sometimes humourously retitled "Fatty Owls","Farty Towels", and even "Flowery Twats"!!!! That last one would never have made it onto an American network other than PBS!

I like John Cleese, but perhaps this is a case where I just couldn't find myself liking this show.

  Go for it, if you like John Cleese in general, but that is really one of the only really good things about the show!

The regularly seen quuartet of actors definitely are rather quiet talking and the show takes bizarre turns in plot. It is definitely low key. Cleese's presence does explain why the show has so many fans. There are reports of much funnier English tv shows than this one on [...]. I liked Benny Hill Show much better than this anyway.

Come visit the worst-run hotel in the whole of western Europe (well, except for that place in Eastbourne...)

In a field with many top contenders, 'Fawlty Towers' remains my favourite of all 'Britcoms' - situation comedies originating on British television. Fawlty Towers has a cult following decades after the originals aired; it is sometimes hard to believe that there are but 12 episodes, six hours total. The regular cast is led by John Cleese, veteran of the famous Monty Python comedy troupe, as the irrepressible Basil Fawlty, titular head of the hotel with dreams of class and glory; Prunella Scales is his long-suffering and hardworking wife, Sybil, who recognises that while Basil may think 'the sky's the limit!', in fact, '22 rooms is the limit'. Connie Booth (Cleese's real-life wife) played the level-headed and sensible, overworked maid Polly, and in a role matched only by Fawlty's own bizarre manner, Andrew Sachs plays the loveable and ever-incompetent Spanish waiter, Manuel (he's from Barcelona...).  Ballard Berkeley makes Ballard Berkeley makes a regular appearance as the Major, a retired long-term resident at the hotel. Brian Hall joined the cast for the second season as the not-quite-gourmet chef, Terry.

From the very first episode (first aired in 1975) featured a social-climbing Fawlty as perhaps the most rude and insufferable hotel manager in existence, in the resort town of Torquay, on the Channel coast of Britain. Sybil tries to maintain a reasonable level of service, but Fawlty's snobbishness permits him to be gracious (indeed, excessively fawning) toward those he considers 'worthy', which in this episode turns out to be Lord Melbury, who ends up not being Lord Melbury, but rather a confidence trickster, and Fawlty's revenge scares away the real 'posh' guests, whom Fawlty sends off with the hilarious shout, 'Snobs!'

In each of the episodes, there is a crisis - one gets the sense that the life of Fawlty is non-stop crisis, with his wife and Polly forever picking up the pieces, Manuel always complicating things, and the others wandering around in a state of disbelief (or, in the case of the Major, perpetual daze). The twelve episodes highlight all the things that could wrong at hotel in classic comedic fashion - the institution of a Gourmet Night falls flat when the not-quite-recovering alcoholic chef starts drinking the night of the main event; a guest dies in the middle of the night, and Fawlty tries to slip him out unnoticed; remodelers install and remove the wrong doors; the health inspector unexpected shows up and gets served a bit of rat with his cheese.

However, nothing quite matches the kinds of situations Basil can get himself into. When trying to plan a surprise anniversary dinner for his wife, she leaves the hotel thinking that Basil has forgotten again, and Basil dresses Polly up as a sick-bed-bound Sybil to fool the guests. When Polly's friends check in for a wedding over the weekend, Basil suspects the group of free sexual expression (highlighting his own repression); this theme is carried over to a glorious extreme in the episode about the visiting Psychiatrist.

'How does he make his living?' Basil protests. 'He makes his money by sticking his nose into others' private parts, er, details...'

This is also the episode where Sybil finally confronts Basil about his double-sided hotel manner toward guests: 'You're either crawling all over them, licking their boots, or spitting poison at them like some Benzedrine puff adder,' she declares. He replies in perfect form, 'Just trying to enjoy myself, dear.'

As the psychiatrist will comment near the end, there's enough material for an entire psychiatrist conference. Indeed there is, as this is slapstick humour with a difference. Intelligent and witty while utterly chaotic and beyond the pale, one is treated to the moose-head incident and the ingrowing toenail as well as Fawlty's unique form of automobile motivation (how many of us have ever been tempted to whack away at a stalled car with a stick!) and a nice performance of Brahms (his 'third racket', to be precise). One must not overlook the little details, either, including the ever-changing sign in front (the actual hotel used for the exteriors unfortunately burned down many years after the show), and the fact that the interior and exterior layouts of the building cannot correspond (shades of 'The Simpsons' whose furniture layout changes from scene to scene).

It is almost inconceivable that the two series, each of six episodes, were four years apart (1975 and 1979), as they flow rather seamlessly together. Popular on television networks worldwide, it can be seen variously on BBC America and local public television channels, often during the fund drives, when the most popular pieces are shown.

The DVD has various extras, including interviews with Cleese, Scales and Sachs (Booth was not available); there are director's commentaries as well as a tour of the now-abandoned hotel used for the exterior (a rather bizarre piece, that). The extras are sadly substandard, but the series itself is excellent, and worth having in the digital format.

This series is exceedingly hard to watch. Hard - because it's almost impossible to get past watching the first episode. That alone is a satisfying banquet that you will want to repeat over and over, wiithout going further to sample the rest. Having finally done that, it's difficult to pick a favorite episode, and it's arguable that any single one in the collection is, alone, worth the price of the whole.

In the first episode alone, we're treated to some brilliant, classic (and nearly indescribable) situations: "On Those Trays (Burro! Hee-haw!)" and "Throw - It - AWAY!" (It's difficult to write this, without cracking up.) The slapstick is tastefully done. I don't know if it's true or not, but it gives the impression of being cleverly improvised on the spot, rather than slickly planned and rehearsed. Cleese and Company should be very proud indeed.

After a bad day, this DVD never fails to cheer me up. It's an essential, essential addition to any DVD collection.

I have seen the British series, Black Adder, and I definitely like Fawlty Towers better. This is what I call intelligent comedy as contrasted with the surfacy silly crapp we get so much during Prime Time TV. You know, boy and girl joke about stupid stuff. Having said this, you must understand that I am also a major fan of Three's Company which doesn't take much of a brain to appreciate! If you like Three's Company and Peter Seller's Pink Panther you will frikkin' love Fawlty Towers.

Far funnier and consistent than any other John Cleese

work (yes, better than any Monty Python product, although

some of their greatest hits collections could come close).

Wonderful array of characters and relationships, great wit,

sarcasm, and delightfully derogatory and playfully petulant.

The use of a half dozen sets keeps the action fresh, including

an infrequent outdoor shot.  Cleese frantically zings and slings, Booth steers the ship, Sybil's the foil, and Manuel

is ever manic as the Coronel walks in the effervescent fog of it all.  12 tight yet frolicking episodes in the greatest hotel no one wants to visit. "Right! Well...this is it! I'm going to give you a damn good thrashing!!!"

The only harsh criticism I could possibly rail against the Fawlty Towers series is that it ended much too soon. This collection is comedy at its finest; the talented ensemble cast, the quaint hotel setting, and the incredibly genius plots all work together charmingly in creating laughter in abundance, some of it quite rioutous and unavoidably laugh-out-loud. My absolute favorites are "Basil the Rat," "Communication Problems," and "The Psychiatrist." However, they are all first rate. Enjoy. Cheerio.

Lots of very visual humour. Show translated and shown in about 80 different countries. Best $50 you can spend on a DVD. As good as it gets. I watch episodes over and over again and they are just as funny as the first time.

John Cleese is Basil Fawlty, a hotel manager trying to please only those who have a lot of money or fame. He is dominated by his overbearing wife & has an inept waiter to deal with. (He's from Barcelona) The only brains in the whole outfit is Polly. 12 episodes of hilarity. Watch the sign outside the hotel. Something always happens to it.
The selection was for a Birthday, his 22nd and he enjoyed the dvd.  Also the price was a good bargain.
Great series.  John Cleese has once again made me laugh so hard!

One wonders if they had this type of comedy for the US of A, would we be a bit more literate?  The group that put Fawlty Towers together were classic writers of the Classic Brits view of "funny".  John Cleese does his slow takes so well, while his wife, Prunella Scales is the epitomy of Matriarchal!  Connie Booth as a co-writer and support for "Mr. Fawlty", excels herself as a comedienne and talent.  And of course there is Manuel, from Barcelona, who often times has the job of taking the blame for all of "fawlty's" faults.  My jacket on my DVD calls it the Sistine Chapel of sitcoms.  I buy that!!
Fawlty Towers is just the best of the Best... I can watch it over and over again.
fawlty towers was very funny. the british comedy has a wonderful since of humor that all the family can watch.

John Cleese's tour-de-force is easily one of the greatest comedies ever to appear on TV. His masterful job as Basil will have you laughing throughout every episode. I've seen these shows dozens of times and they're still hysterical. Anyone who's ever been divorced will find them even funnier.
This is a side splitting, laughing out loud dvd set.  I promise you will absolutely enjoy this and watch and rewatch it many times.  My teenage son loves it also.

I remember this series when it was first broadcast in the US.  It was funny then and funny now.  I don't know why they did not produce more of this series or revise it.  It is fast paced and you have to listen carefully or you will miss half the jokes, you also have to be somewhat literate to enjoy Basil's retorts.  Buy this and share it with only your intellegent friends.
Fawlty Towers is the number one comedy series of all time. The episode: "The Germans" is the best comedy sitcom episode ever.
A classic piece of British comedy that is a must in any DVD library.

I've just moved to the USA from England and was pleasantly surprised to find i could get this classic series on DVD over here.  I grew up watching this and will never tire of hearing Manuel say 'que?'.  Some bits may be a little politically incorrect for today's society, but for me that's where the beauty lies.  An excellent series unfortunately cut short, but probably all better for it (and it helps keep the price reasonable).  If you've got this far and are still reading, stop now and buy it, the only regret you'll have is having waited so long!!

It's such a shame only 12 episodes were made...
This is great English comedy... in fact great universal comedy..
I loved it... John Cleese is a Genius.

Along with The Thin Blue Line, Yes Minister & Yes Prime Minister, this show is at the very pinnacle of British TV Comedy serials. John Cleese is the star of the show of course (when is he not), but Andrew Sachs as Manuel comes a very close second. The rest of the cast too is brilliant, and the script is pure magic. Every episode was a gem, and the second season was every bit as good as the first (rare in such shows). My only regret about this serial, is that there was such a small number of episodes (maybe John Cleese may read this review & come out with the third season).

Fawlty Towers has been a long-time favorite of mine.  I usually laugh out loud at the hilarious John Cleese and his absurd antics.  Some can't appreciate British humor (and I don't know why!) but I plead with you to give it a try.  Fawlty Towers is worth your time and $$.  Here's a tip when watching: check out the hotel sign for it's ever-changing name (ex. Watery Towels, Warty Fowls, etc.).  The show is a kick-in-the-pants.  Enjoy!

I remember hearing an interview with Cleese, where he said the Faultys were based on his parents. Basil and Sybil are not supposed to be nice people. If you have ever known people like the Faultys, you will identify with it and realize that Cleese is finding humor in the things he endured as a child.
Although Fawlty Towers was a low-budget British TV comedy program that was inexplicably cancelled after a few episodes, it had excellent writing and funny scripts.

The real prize element of this collection is that it shows Cleese's side of the MONTY PYTHON team, as well as being a great show piece for  Connie Booth's writing skills. It is very evident that this body of work is culturally specific in it's overall sense of humour: Whilst it is clear that US audiences enjoy the series( and some most definitely do not), the things that are liked are different to the way a British audience will perceive the series.

There are three  seasons in this collection, not the two as usually stated. Three seasons, three discs...

The writing is incredibly precise. You can see this in the published versions of the scripts. In this respect, it has the same skilled basis for good performers as the Python Material. But where the Python team did not know where to stop, Cleese and Booth decided to leave it at three seasons, and so whilst there is a demand there for more of this material, Cleese and Booth wanted to leave on a high note.

It's incredibly hard to give a precise of each show, since the writers blocked out the story flows on charts over 6 week  periods, and basically agonized  over every word. These shows were done with an eye for precision, and in this respect they were an extension of the Python  process for writing, since each show ( FAWLTY TOWERS as well as seasons 1-3 of MONTY PYTHON) is an example of detailed work.

All this adds up to a body of work that stands up to repeated viewing, and has a degree of universality ( like YES MINISTER, and  YES  PRIME MINISTER, but the YES... MINISTER  series are much more  Universal). And I suspect that the writers and producers never expected this series to have the longevity it has attained ( Much the same way that Ben Elton has stated that THE YOUNG ONES is very clearly  dated, since it was targeted for specific  times and specific  events); however, FAWLTY TOWERS looks at some Universal  elements in life, and in  British  experience.

Undoubtedly, FAWLTY TOWERS is perennial, but it is mainly perennial for the British  experience; a US  audience will like it to some degree, but the appeal is fundamentally  different. It is not that it is less, just different.

All that Being said, I can recommend this collection as being a great body of work. As an example of low budget British TV comedy that has at its heart a Superb script, one can but hope that TV in general, in all places, irrespective of the budget, will look to great scripts, and let the story telling be augmented by great performers ( such as Cleese), each to their own milieu ( Cultural, or whatever), or even if aimed at a world audience. Key to the understanding of the cultural  specificity, is how Manuel changes from being Spanish in the original  series, and then in the Spanish, he is Italian, and in each different language dub, the Archetype selected for Manuel changes  according to how each dub version will select a different nationality to be the butt of the jokes... and the way these jokes are translated tell more about the culture they are being reworked into than they do about the original  version of the show.

At once a very simple show, but it can be seen on many levels; however, if you don't get it, if you don't find the shows funny, remember that these ARE shows done for a particular Milieu; a better example of more Universal comedy from the BBC, is something like YES MINISTER ( not to say that this higher budget work is better, simply different).

My dad was always into Monty Python and other sundry Brittish Comedy, so I grew up watching John Cleese and all the others.  He never owned Fawlty Towers but told me to watch it if I ever got the chance.  I was browsing Amazon one day and saw it on DVD, and I purchased it.  I am so glad I did!  I can say, the only Fawlt is that the series was cancelled after only 12 episodes!

I first found Fawlty Towers while in high school on my local PBS station.  Years later I bought the collection on VHS and I'll occasionally pull one out and watch it.  Some of the episodes are just as funny today as they were 25+ years ago.  If it wasn't for some vet bills right now, I'd probably run out and get these on DVD for the better quality and the hope of some good extras.

What makes Fawlty Tower's work is Basil's arrogance, his fear/contempt/love of his wife, and his ability to always do the wrong thing even when he is trying to do the right thing.  My favorite episode is the one where the guy sneaks the girl into his room.  The image of Basil tapping on the glass as if he is inspecting it is pure comic genius.

I was sorely disappointed with the American version a few years ago with John Laroquette.  They tried to portray the Fawlty's marriage as being loving, where is the fun in that?  The remake lacked any of the edginess of the original.

Overall, Fawlty Towers was simply one of the funniest shows ever.  It's a shame they didn't make more.

As a teenager, I became hooked on the local PBS station, in large part due to the number of BBC produced sitcoms they would show. "Are You Being Served?", "Man About The House", and most notably "Fawlty Towers."

As a big "Monty Python" fan, I was totally unprepared for the more sophisticated humor in "Fawlty Towers". John Cleese as Basil Fawlty, the proprietor of a somewhat dodgy inn, is as over the top in this series as he ever was. Fans of Cleese's contributions to Python won't be disappointed.

Basil is rude, incompetent and extremely condescending. He consistently attempts to bully his patrons into following his own schedule, adapting to his own mannerisms and submitting to his will in general. Unfortunately for Basil, most of the patrons staying at the inn refuse to conform, and rightly so. The end result usually involves Basil being disgraced, humiliated and deflated.

Basil's wife Sybil, played by Prunella Scales, is bossy, lazy and ineffective. Half of Sybil's life seems dedicated to barking orders to her husband, the other half to talking on the phone, chatting with customers or eating bon-bons.

Polly, the maid/waitress, serves as Basil's partner in crime. When things go wrong, and they always do, it becomes Polly's job to help hide the evidence, usually from Sybil.

Manuel is from Barcelona.

Each episode of "Fawlty Towers" is truly a comedy of errors, the moral of which (if one needs a moral) might be: "Don't be like Basil." As things snowball out of control, Basil's and Polly's attempts to get a handle on the situation (usually while keeping everything from Sybil) result in some of the best comedic moments in television history.

Each episode of the series is completely unique and may be watched separately; it doesn't take long to catch on to the characters and how they interact. Additionally, Cleese and Booth  put their unique stamp on the script, with lines just as quotable as anything from "Monty Python" or "Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy".

Because there are only 12 episodes total, the writing, the acting and the laughs stay top notch throughout. This isn't a collection one buys to get a couple of favorite episodes. The extras on the DVD mirror the series by being just right. Some commentary, some interviews, a couple of sidepieces, and that's it. No Hollywood flash, just things that will interest any fan of the series.

One of the things I liked best about "Fawlty Towers" when watching it years ago, was that I could watch it with my Dad. The humor isn't universal. Some of it is dark, and most definitely a bit offbeat. Still, it's accessible enough that many people who don't care about the Spanish Inquisition, much less whether anyone expects it or not, will enjoy the train wreck that is Basil Fawlty.

Where have you been hiding if you have never seen an episode of this BBC treasure trove?  Fawlty Towers is easily BBC's best comedy, bar none.  Filmed over two seasons (1975 and 1979), the show featured clever, witty and engaging scripts allowing for plenty of re-watch factor.  A stellar cast included John Cleese and Prunella Scales.  It is very difficult to pick a favourite scene, but safe to say that are all outstanding.

This is a DVD you can purchase without doubt.  Picture quality is outstanding in comparison to the video version.  Yes, the price may be high, but it is worth every single penny.

This is the British Comedy by which all others are measured!

Do not pay any attention to the idiot's that gave this a bad review.  They obviously have no sense of humor or just don't get British humor.  This is a must see/buy!  You shall not be disappointed.

It's a crime I say!!!  How can there only be 12 of these gems in the world?  I searched and searched and then I found out that this is all there is.  There ain't no more folks.  Fawlty Towers is funny for more than one reason.  Generally, British sitcoms are not as rigid as American sitcoms.  Then there is the language itself.  Pronounciations and accents make things sound even funnier.  I would imagine that you've never called your wife a "stupid cloth eared beet" before.  John Cleese is simply mad.  He's very tall and the sight of him doing his slapstick physical comedy is hilarious.

You can usually see Fawlty Towers and all the other "Britcoms" on PBS but they go through periods where they remove certain shows from the air from time to time.  You may remember John Cleese from his younger days with Monty Python's Flying Circus, which I didn't watch for years because I thought it was a circus show.  What a fool was I.

Here are some of my favorites that you simply must see:

The Corpse and the Kipper - A guest dies during the night but when Basil Fawlty brings his breafast in the morning he doesn't even notice the guy is dead!

The Health Inspector - The Health Inspector comes to perform a suprise inspection.  Little does Basil know that Manuel has a pet rat that gets loose in the hotel.  Manuel thinks it's a hamster.  Everyone tries to catch the rat while keeping it hush-hush from the inspector.  This episode is wild.

The Germans - Basil Fawlty's done himself a mischief and gotten a concusion.  He leaves the hospital insisting that he's okay because the Germans are coming and he must be there.  Add that to the fact that he can't speak German and watch the fun.

Gourmet Night - Basil tries to cater to the upper crust of British Society by offering a Gourmet Night at the hotel.  It doesn't go well.  The chef (a male) gets drunk and falls in love with Manuel.  There's no dinner to serve and Basil orders it from another restaurant.  He has to pick it up but he gets stuck because the car that he tried to fix himself stops running.  He threatens the car but when that doesn't work, he decides to beat the car with a switch!  When he finally gets back his dinner is not quite what he expected.

The Anniversary - Basil and his wife have a bit of a row (fight) and she leaves just when he's all set to suprise her with a party.  He decides to have the maid pretend that she is his wife.  I can't even explain the rest.  It's too nuts!

You must get this DVD especially if you love Britcoms.  You'll laugh from beginning to end.

I have had this collection for a very long time now and yet I continue to watch each episode over and over again. These episodes - for whatever reason - have great "re-watchability". 12 episodes! Gahaad! I don't know why they made only 12 of these gems, but there ain't nothin' I can do about it, I guess. This collection is superb! The only complaint I have is that the "case" that houses these 3 disks is ungainly and one is forced to lay the thing down flat to unfold it fully. Also dust and dirt can get in from the top and bottom when fully closed. I would have preferred 3 independent fully-protective cases.

Update August 19, 2005:

I just purchased another one of these sets for my mother and she absolutely loves it!

If you were to look up some of the most hysterical moments on the BBC, you would no doubtably come across two names.  Those names would be John Cleese and Ricky Gervais.  While Gervais recently found comedy through his program called "The Office", Cleese has been providing wit, wisdom, and down-right hysteria for the past several decades.  While away from his namesake (Monty Python), you can find Cleese comfortable in several other roles that showcase his bubbling talent.  One of those programs just happens to be the funniest bit of crumpet called "Fawlty Towers".

Remembering this show when I was a child and was on our local PBS station, I eagerly bought it when it was released on DVD about a year ago.  Since then, I have watched random episodes here and there but never fully taking in the enjoyment from watching it all.  So, today I decided to sit down and watch this series from beginning to end and I have yet to finish laughing.  If this program doesn't define comic genius, I don't know what does.  Never have I witnessed a show that has continually been fresh, hysterical (I cannot use that word enough), real, and outlandish all at the same time.  Normally, with our current television programming, you need to pick or choose which it will be, but thankfully "Fawlty Towers" is all of these and many more.

Cleese remains in top form as Basil Fawlty, the owner/manager of the B&B that just happens to have his hands and over-worked imagination in everything.  With the aid of his helpers Manuel (he's from Barcelona) and Polly (co-writer Connie Booth and ex-wife of Cleese), Cleese always seems to find himself in a heap of trouble with his wife Sybil (the dragon of the hotel).  Armed with physical humor and a snake-like banter, we witness everything from a dead body, hotel inspectors, a failed anniversary party, a moose head, and a Himalayan rodent of sorts happen to this simple, everyday, B&B.  This is not only a few of the episodes you will find in the complete set, but also the daily stress that Basil finds himself falling into daily.

This series, again, is hysterical.  Cleese is the master of his trade while proving that he can manage any task thrown in front of him.  While some will argue that he overshadows the rest of the cast, I would say "hogwash" to that.  My two favorite characters in this series were Major and Manuel.  The comedy that they provide cannot be found on television today.  All I need to say is thank God for the BBC.

Grade: ***** out of *****

30 minutes on the lovely "Riviera of England" in the posh Fawlty Towers will raise your spirits.  Basil Fawlty (John Cleese) is the owner/propriator of a small hotel.  Basil has great plans for  raising the 'tone' of the establishment, his wife Sybil just wants to keep the 22 rooms reasonably full of paying guests, Polly (maid of all work) has hopes for escaping and Manuel (the Portugese waiter) would like to get through the day without incurring Basil's wrath.

The episodes are all delightful little gems, Basil attempting to 'thrash' a car into submission, pull one over on Sybil (or a hotel inspector) or catch a con artist (or a rat) are all hilarious.

The extras are also excellent, there interviews with Cleese, Prunella Scales (Sybil) and Andrew Sachs (Manuel) that supply entertaining insights into the series, as does the director's commentary.  There is also information on the various actors who made guest appearances in the series as well as a section of out-takes.

Truly funny sitcom. Frankly, though I like some of Cleese's later portrayals, Basil Fawlty is his best work ever. Clever in the idea, the ensemble, the writing, Fawlty Towers is hilarious. It should have gone on for several seasons. If you like Frasier for the multi-layered and higher level humor that exceeds the sophomoric in some of the current television shows, then you'll like this wacky hotel. I'm not sure in today's politically correct world that this sitcom could even be made, which makes it possibly more valuable.

Few TV shows pass what I call the ultimate DVD test: is it so well done that you'll want to watch it again and again, and still get pleasure. Fawlty Towers ranks with the Honeymooners at the top of this select class. The similarities are thought-provoking. Both were "filmed" on a remarkably spare, almost theatrical sets. Both featured what might be called choreographed physical comedy as well as wit, whether it was John Cleese goosestepping his way through "Germans" or Jackie Gleason doing the Hucklebuck with Art Carney and "Mrs. Manicotti." I've watched every episode at least a dozen times over the years, and like fine wine, it seems only to improve with age. By all means buy this priceless collection.

Come visit the worst-run hotel in the whole of western Europe (well, except for that place in Eastbourne...)

In a field with many top contenders, 'Fawlty Towers' remains my favourite of all 'Britcoms' - situation comedies originating on British television.  Fawlty Towers has a cult following decades after the originals aired; it is sometimes hard to believe that there are but 12 episodes, six hours total.  The regular cast is led by John Cleese, veteran of the famous Monty Python comedy troupe, as the irrepressible Basil Fawlty, titular head of the hotel with dreams of class and glory; Prunella Scales is his long-suffering and hardworking wife, Sybil, who recognises that while Basil may think 'the sky's the limit!', in fact, '22 rooms is the limit'.  Connie Booth (Cleese's real-life wife) played the level-headed and sensible, overworked maid Polly, and in a role matched only by Fawlty's own bizarre manner, Andrew Sachs plays the loveable and ever-incompetent Spanish waiter, Manuel (he's from Barcelona...).  Ballard Berkeley makes a regular appearance as the Major, a retired long-term resident at the hotel.  Brian Hall joined the cast for the second season as the not-quite-gourmet chef, Terry.

From the very first episode (first aired in 1975) featured a social-climbing Fawlty as perhaps the most rude and insufferable hotel manager in existence, in the resort town of Torquay, on the Channel coast of Britain.  Sybil tries to maintain a reasonable level of service, but Fawlty's snobbishness permits him to be gracious (indeed, excessively fawning) toward those he considers 'worthy', which in this episode turns out to be Lord Melbury, who ends up not being Lord Melbury, but rather a confidence trickster, and Fawlty's revenge scares away the real 'posh' guests, whom Fawlty sends off with the hilarious shout, 'Snobs!'

In each of the episodes, there is a crisis - one gets the sense that the life of Fawlty is non-stop crisis, with his wife and Polly forever picking up the pieces, Manuel always complicating things, and the others wandering around in a state of disbelief (or, in the case of the Major, perpetual daze).  The twelve episodes highlight all the things that could wrong at hotel in classic comedic fashion - the institution of a Gourmet Night falls flat when the not-quite-recovering alcoholic chef starts drinking the night of the main event; a guest dies in the middle of the night, and Fawlty tries to slip him out unnoticed; remodelers install and remove the wrong doors; the health inspector unexpected shows up and gets served a bit of rat with his cheese.

However, nothing quite matches the kinds of situations Basil can get himself into.  When trying to plan a surprise anniversary dinner for his wife, she leaves the hotel thinking that Basil has forgotten again, and Basil dresses Polly up as a sick-bed-bound Sybil to fool the guests.  When Polly's friends check in for a wedding over the weekend, Basil suspects the group of free sexual expression (highlighting his own repression); this theme is carried over to a glorious extreme in the episode about the visiting Psychiatrist.

'How does he make his living?' Basil protests.  'He makes his money by sticking his nose into others' private parts, er, details...'

This is also the episode where Sybil finally confronts Basil about his double-sided hotel manner toward guests: 'You're either crawling all over them, licking their boots, or spitting poison at them like some Benzedrine puff adder,' she declares.  He replies in perfect form, 'Just trying to enjoy myself, dear.'

As the psychiatrist will comment near the end, there's enough material for an entire psychiatrist conference.  Indeed there is, as this is slapstick humour with a difference.  Intelligent and witty while utterly chaotic and beyond the pale, one is treated to the moose-head incident and the ingrowing toenail as well as Fawlty's unique form of automobile motivation (how many of us have ever been tempted to whack away at a stalled car with a stick!) and a nice performance of Brahms (his 'third racket', to be precise).
